caption:
On Sunday RISD NY alumni met up at Everything is Design, a show on the work of revered designer Paul Rand, at the Museum of the City of New York. A great group of 30 people of all ages joined NY Club Leader and Alumni Council member Will McLoughlin BArch 09 and a docent to view the show. Keep your ear to the ground for other interesting events coming up for RISD NY!

photos by Aliona Katz 92 IL

caption:
With the balance of a ballerina, Stella Zhong 15 GL bounded up a set of uneven stairs built into the side of a towering platform. The immense structure was the central component of unnameable, her senior thesis installation – which just wrapped up last Wednesday at a vacant office building in downtown Providence.

“I wanted viewers to feel a bit off-kilter when climbing up [the tower],” Zhong explained at the opening reception. “The show is about moments in life when the world feels a bit unstable.”

Visitors also stumbled upon mirrors, small golf balls and even a paper cup that shook unexpectedly – all placed in various nooks and crannies in the airy space. Some of the bravest show-goers entered a small closet housing a brick installation lit from the inside.

“This exhibition is a collection of subtle optical illusions,” noted longtime Professor of Glass Bruce Chao 73 SC/MFA 75 GL. “It’s a surreal, wondrous environment to explore.”

caption:
RISD returned to NY Design Week again this year, with staff from Alumni Relations, the Career Center, Academic Affairs and Furniture Design (among others) touring the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, Wanted Design, Sight Unseen Offsite, the National Stationery Show and various other shows around the city – including an exhibition of work by students from Furniture Design at ICFF.  

Alumni Relations hosted a Design Week reception at Wanted Design’s hip new Brooklyn location in Industry City, where guests got the chance to hear from President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID.

There was a lot to celebrate, with Kjartan Oskarsson MFA 14 FD winning WantedDesign’s Launch Pad Award, Egg Collective (including Crystal Ellis MFA 11 SC) winning American Design Honors (also from WantedDesign), and Ladyfingers Letterpress (one half Morgan Calderini 07 PR) grabbing six Louie Awards, including Card of the Year, at the International Greeting Card Awards Competition.

Find more on the RISD xNYC Design Week site or RISD’s Instagram page.

photos by Rebecca Greenfield 97 PH

caption:
At the opening reception for the Printmaking and Ceramics Senior Exhibition in Woods-Gerry Gallery last Thursday, Rebecca Kim 15 CR (top photo) flitted around her ceramics pieces in a winged black dress. Her work is inspired by one of nature’s most magical creatures: the monarch butterfly.

“The life cycle of this small creature is a miracle,” Kim notes. “They’re resilient animals who retreat into a dark cocoon and later emerge with the power to fly. These insects give me hope when l feel overwhelmed. They remind me that every struggle builds inner strength.”

At the opening, a large crowd stood transfixed by You See I Got It All I Am Who I Am: Mae Innovation Man (second photo), a looping video directed by Elisa Palluau 15 CR. In the piece, a shadowy figure – wearing dark sunglasses and a gas mask – lights a cigarette and arranges a collection of liquor bottles on a long table. Lumpy ceramic spheres and plaster pebbles are scattered on the hardwood floors in front of the screen.

Other visitors chuckled at Boys and Beer (third photo), a set of 50 whimsical prints by Sophia Oldsman 15 PR. In one, a young bearded man sips a beer next to a roaring campfire. Another shows a man drinking while standing in the shower fully clothed. Others depict men sitting on couches with small lap dogs.

The show closed today but if you missed it, you can still see images of the work online.

caption:
Chatting with friends in the RISD President’s House, Denali Schmidt 15 FAV reaches toward a plate of cubed watermelon topped with balls of fried waterbugs (top photo). She pops the delicacy in her mouth and takes a moment to appreciate the delicate flavors. “This is surprisingly tasty – even though it’s made from aquatic insects!” she exclaims. “I’m going to have another.”

Schmidt was among the 75 adventuresome foodies at last Saturday’s Bug Banquet II, a lovely dinner party organized by Chloé Bulpin 15 IL (see Go Eat Worms!). 

With the help of Alex Gandarillas, Matt Kominsky, Luis Rivera, Katie Riley, Erik Bielfeld, David Lefkowitz and Jacob Rich, who are all majoring in culinary arts at Johnson & Wales University, the environmentally conscious senior hopes to make eating bugs – a protein-rich, sustainable food source consumed by approximately 80% of the world’s population – more acceptable and routine in the US.

“I’m so glad to have been able to introduce so many people to a new culinary option,” notes Bulpin. “There were quite a few hesitant guests who were pleasantly surprised by the diverse flavors on the menu.”

Also in attendance were members of the RISD Parents’ Council, the JWU Nutrition Society and the RISD Dinner Club – including Alice Taranto 15 GD, Mei Lenehan 18 FS and Kathryn LaMontagne 18 FS. 

“RISD does not support the raising of genetically modified crickets,” quipped a bug-headed Harri Taranto, co-chair of the RISD Parents’ Council, posing with President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID (second photo from bottom). “We only support free-range, hormone-free insects.”

In the main living room, Gabriel Matesanz 18 FS sampled skewers of crickets and silkworm battered in crispy tempura. He washed down a final bite with a generous sip from a glass of citrus spiced cider. “The texture isn’t what you’d expect,” he admits. “But it’s really quite good. I’d recommend this dish to friends.” 

Nearby, Joseph Sands 15 FD and Melanie Chang 17 FD nibbled on squares of sundried tomato, roasted artichoke, mozzarella and pesto flatbread made from cricket flour. “It’s common for people in Thailand to eat pan-fried crickets. They’re cheap to produce and really healthy,” notes Sands. “I hope this trend takes off in Western cultures.”

photos by Patrick Han 15 FAV

caption:
This week New York-based designer Marcia Patmos 91 AP (top photo, center) won the 2015 International Woolmark Prize for womenswear – an honor that comes with $100,000, along with international distribution via such outlets as Harvey Nichols and Saks Fifth Avenue.

At the competition finals in Beijing on March 17, a team of judges – including editors from Vogue Italia and Vogue China and fashionista Victoria Beckham – chose M.PATMOS Merino wool streetwear for the top prize. After winning the 2014/15 US Wookmark Prize last summer, Patmos was competing against 60 womenswear designers from 21 countries for the international prize. 

“I am really excited to be here in Beijing to be part of this event,” Beckham told British Vogue. “I feel that Patmos embodies best what the Woolmark Prize stands for. The collection is well executed and the concept interesting.” 

Vogue Italia editor Franca Sozzani applauds Patmos’ “easy concept” – the woman of today. “Very cool and simple, but very well made … It’s perfect for daily wear.”

caption:
At last Thursday’s opening reception for the Painting Senior Exhibition at Woods-Gerry Gallery, Zoe Clark 16 TX slowly paced before Transferred, a vivid oil painting by Danny Glass 15 PT (pictured in third row). 

“I don’t typically reference this palette in my own textiles,” the junior noted. “But I love how the lightest part of the model’s pale yellow hair is one of the background shades. This has definitely given me food for thought.”

On another side of the gallery, Tomas Hernando Kofman 16 PT inspected a whimsical piece by SoHee Kim 15 PT, who twisted balls of multicolored Play-Doh before sticking it on a naked canvas (fifth row).

“The use of such a playful material makes this piece relatable to viewers. You can easily see how it was made,” Kofman noted. “But the blank canvas also gives it a muted, somber feeling.”

Hazel Elsbach 18 FS and Grace Chung 18 FS were intrigued by tiny watercolor and gouache paintings by Sarah Vite 15 PT. “There’s something humble about these small vignettes,” Elsbach noted. “I think the scale lends a certain sweetness.”

Hazel Elsbach 18 FS and Grace Chung 18 FS were intrigued by tiny watercolor and gouache paintings by Sarah Vite 15 PT. “There’s something humble about these small vignettes,” Elsbach noted. “I think the scale lends a certain sweetness.”
trail.content_raw:
At last Thursday’s opening reception for the Painting Senior Exhibition at Woods-Gerry Gallery, Zoe Clark 16 TX slowly paced before Transferred, a vivid oil painting by Danny Glass 15 PT (pictured in third row). 

“I don’t typically reference this palette in my own textiles,” the junior noted. “But I love how the lightest part of the model’s pale yellow hair is one of the background shades. This has definitely given me food for thought.”

On another side of the gallery, Tomas Hernando Kofman 16 PT inspected a whimsical piece by SoHee Kim 15 PT, who twisted balls of multicolored Play-Doh before sticking it on a naked canvas (fifth row).

“The use of such a playful material makes this piece relatable to viewers. You can easily see how it was made,” Kofman noted. “But the blank canvas also gives it a muted, somber feeling.”

Hazel Elsbach 18 FS and Grace Chung 18 FS were intrigued by tiny watercolor and gouache paintings by Sarah Vite 15 PT. “There’s something humble about these small vignettes,” Elsbach noted. “I think the scale lends a certain sweetness.”

Sarah Vite 15 PT makes small watercolor and gouache paintings.

Jennifer Murray 15 PT presents Cacti, a large acrylic painting.

caption:
When the Atlanta suburb of East Roswell, GA cleared a plot of land near the Chattahochee River in order to build a new library, the town used its percent for the arts initiative to commission local sculptor Chris Condon 95 SC to bring some of the lost flora and fauna from the site right into the building. 

Working for almost two years, Condon created his New Growth Forest series of laminated and carved wooden sculptures primarily using salvaged construction materials and an old oak tree that was cut down on the site. 

“The idea is when the site was cleared all the flora and fauna were disrupted, so they have now come inside and taken up residency in the library,” Condon notes, adding that he sees his work “as hybrids rather than replicas” of what he sees in nature. “Climbing on bookshelves, perched in young trees that grew up inside the architecture, the animals are now going about their daily routines [inside the library].”

caption:
At last Thursday’s opening reception for the Apparel Design exhibition now at Woods-Gerry, Noah Berch 15 AP invites friends to inspect his snappy collection of womenswear inspired by 1950’s fashion staples (pictured in the third row). The senior made the pleated skirts and collared tank tops using a combination of flexible fabrics with a subtle sparkle. As one of his models makes a slight turn, he gestures toward her lined blouse.

“There’s a hidden surprise in this piece,” Berch explains to a small group gathered around his work. “The front looks conservative but there’s a dramatic opening in the back – a modern twist on this classic silhouette. After researching the professional roles women assumed during the World War II era, I was fascinated by the idea of female conformity – and how they rebelled against subordinate roles after the men returned home.”

At the opening, viewers happily roamed between handknit children’s costumes, expertly tailored suit coats, futuristic loungewear, geometric onesies and other examples of stylish, avant-garde garb.

For instance, Colin LoCascio 15 AP presented plastic turtlenecks, pierced pants and other garments made from neoprene, vinyl and angora wool. In the main hall, live models wearing Congenital I and Congenital II (first and fifth rows) drew many amazed looks from the crowd, who were impressed with the bulbous suits Andrea Dyes 15 AP made from latex, foam and fabric. Fashions fit for a hip tomboy – made by Elizabeth Hilfiger 15 AP – also attracted attention (sixth row, left).

In addition, a beige coat and jumpsuit designed by Chaz Aracil 15 AP is one of the most elegant designs in the show (which closes tomorrow). “I made this in my junior year out of wool and leather,” he explains as a striking model shows of the garment (pictured bottom row). “I learned how to sew these types of large pieces by hand – which is such an important skill for an apparel designer.”

caption: Newly-minted Houston club leaders Katie Schon 05 GD and Falon Mihalic 12 MLA held a very well-attended meet up at the Post Oak Whole Foods a few weeks ago.  As Katie wrote: “The RISD Houston Alumni Chapter kicked off with roughly 20 attendees at our inaugural happy hour, ranging from the class of 1984 to the class of 2014. We ate good food, drank good beer (the happy hour was at Houston’s new Whole Foods, which happens to be the only Whole Foods in the country that brews their own beer), and had a lot of catching up to do on majors, careers, life in Houston, and personal RISD histories. We’re excited to connect with the Houston RISD alumni and look forward to getting together again soon.”

caption:
Students enrolled in Iron in Winter – a Wintersession studio taught by Sculpture faculty member Chris Sancomb 93 SC and grad student Megan Tamas MFA 15 SC – got a crash course in ironworking last month. As this risd.edu story explains, the five-week class culminated in a fiery full-day “iron pour” during which students ladled molten metal into molds they’d made from ceramic composites, wood and dried mud. 

photos by Abigail Crocker

photos.caption: Students in the Wintersession Sculpture studio Iron in Winter unearthed a captivating collection of metalwork.
Two students pound on old iron radiators and bathtubs with sledgehammers to break them into baseball-sized pieces that were then loaded into a homemade blast furnace.
Joe Fellows 16 SC made a collection of foot-long fish he made using molds of large herring preserved in formaldehyde.
Engaged in the "iron pour,” a group of students wearing leather jackets and face shields work outdoors in the bitter cold behind the Metcalf Building.
Some molds were made out of ceramic composites, wood and dried mud.
Students ladle scoops of molten-hot metal into molds during a full-day “iron pour.”
The “cupola” – a homemade blast furnace – is heated with coke, which is derived from coal but has minimal impurities.

caption:
Without any hesitation, Rana Ozdeslik plops herself on Cat Me If You Can, a furry chair hooked up to an iPhone. The device is engaged in a live video chat with MIT students standing next to a twin version of the piece housed in a Cambridge, MA gallery. 

Suddenly the plush installation (pictured in the top photo) emits a looping, high-pitched meow.“It quiets down when you pet the arm piece – a section of the chair that’s connected to sensors,” the Brown student explains. “Once it’s pacified, the [identical piece] in Cambridge makes a purring sound.”

The captivating cat chair is among the many futuristic devices on display at Thursday’s opening reception for Body + Internet, an exhibition on view at RISD Exposé and MIT's Industry Lab. Over the last four weeks, students from RISD, Brown and MIT worked together to make thought-provoking devices while mastering technical skills in electronics, digital fabrication and programming. Organized by members of RISD’s STEAM group, the show explores our ability as humans to express sentimentality through technological and digital means.

In another corner of the gallery, students gather around Lifeloggin’ Thoughtz, which shows Amelia Zhang 15 PT wearing a decorated jumpsuit and a GoPro, which takes pictures of her surroundings every 30 seconds. Posted to a Tumblr blog, the images explore issues of privacy and image ownership.

“This work’s aesthetic is rooted in '90s tech nostalgia,” writes Zhang in her artist’s statement. “It appeals to the first generation of Internet natives who grew up playing with Tamagotchis and Microsoft paint.”

Visitors at the opening we also drawn to Voy(eur)age, an installation in a ‘projection room’ with two live feeds. In it webcams record viewers’ every move and send this imagery to a 'peephole’ set up in the sister location. In turn, the RISD version sends out its own captured visual data.

“Our blogs are diaries and our Instagrams collect embarrassing selfies. We hope a voyeur in the audience will initiate a direct relationship,” notes Genevieve Marsh BArch 15. “By giving both parties the same ability to initiate interaction, [I’m asking] what happens when they realize they are voyeurs of the other.”

caption:
At last Thursday’s opening reception for the Film/Animation/Video Triennial – highlighting some of the best work emanating from the department in the last three years – a cluster of RISD students look up into the saucer-like eyes of an alien creature outfitted in a white jacket and matching pants (pictured in bottom row). The human-sized prop is included in a video montage featuring otherworldly pieces students made in Creature-Creation, a Wintersession course taught by faculty member Erminio Pinque 83 IL of Big Nazo Lab.

Elsewhere at Woods-Gerry Gallery, Tess Wagman 18 FS (pictured in top row) is captivated by scenes of an angry King Kong batting away an airplane in Ligget Ln., an animated piece by Taylor Beldy 15 FAV. “This is beautiful,” she notes. “I’ve never seen an animation incorporate elements of printmaking. There’s so much detail here and great use of light.”

In a darkened room, a seated audience watches Shelf Life, the dark comedy Brett Van Egmond 13 FAV made a couple of years ago as his final degree project (video above). Some smile at a miniature set made for Saturday, a quirky stop-motion animation directed by Joanne Lin 16 FAV.

Like moths to a flame, many visitors are also drawn to Mirror, videos of young women shouting into bullhorns or sporting snake-like hair pieces. Jacqueline Lin 15 FAV projected the pieces on suspended canvas (pictured in third row). “These vignettes are really powerful,” explains Evan Grothjan 15 FAV .“You can’t help but take notice of these characters. They’re really well produced.”

Catch the triennial if you can. The show closes on Sunday, February 15.

caption:
Wearing sturdy boots, Mengxuan Liu MLA 17 trudges to the outskirts of Tillinghast Farm – RISD’s property on the bay in Barrington, RI – and scoops up a small container of grainy soil. He would later examine the physical properties of the fragrant material when designing an outdoor classroom for the premises.

“When I conducted a series of tests on the farm’s soil,” explains Liu, “I learned how the material binds together, how it responds to force and the ways in which water moves through it. These are all important variables to consider when making plans for an outdoor site.”

The Chinese-born artist explained his work at last week’s opening reception for Landscape Architecture: Principles + Process, an exhibition on view through Sunday at Sol Koffler Graduate Student Gallery. The show focuses on the work  MLA candidates produced in last fall’s Design Principles studio, which focused on the Tillinghast Farm site.

Taught by Assistant Professor Suzanne Mathew, Critic Adam Anderson MLA 12 and Professor Colgate Searle BLA 71, the course pushes students to explore issues of design thinking, investigative making and conceptual development. Projects are inspired by all aspects of the bayside site  – natural light, wind patterns, marshy vegetation and even moisture levels in the sandy soil.

“The students are learning through the process of experimentation and collecting hard data,” notes Anderson. “They’ve come up with some beautiful concepts.”

caption:
Things have been heating up for regional alumni clubs lately, with RISD Miami and Hawaii hosting notable affairs in January. The Miami event at the Art Center/South Florida was the kickoff for the new club, set up by leader Jayda Knight Uras 99 IA; attendees were able to visit studios of RISD artists in residence while mingling. Across the continent, Jamie Allen 05 IL took up the reins from recently relocated Melissa Rivera 01 ID/MAT 05 and organized a very successful and well-attended get-together. Jamie wrote: 

RISD alumni in Hawaii met at a new bar in Kakaako, which is an up-and-coming artistic mecca housing the mural project Pow Wow… Personally I am looking forward to more of these events so we can continue the dialogue and support one another. Hawaii is made up of several islands, so it’s hard for everyone to meet up, but I am pleased to see our network growing and remaining strong. Aloha!

caption:
In a spirited exercise that resembles speed dating, Textiles faculty members rush from room to room in the College Building critiquing student work. They are taken with a large, brightly colored piece by Panalee (Mint) Pitaksuteephong 16 TX (top photo) inspired by a pond full of koi.

“You’ve really put us in the water with the fish,” says Assistant Professor and Department Head Brooks Hagan MFA 02 TX. Assistant Professor Mary Anne Friel appreciates the sense of movement in the work and praises the student’s choice of fabrics, noting, “The herringbone is so unexpected. It gives the piece wonderful texture.”

After reviewing all of Pitaksuteephong’s samples and patterns, the team of faculty moves on to view a collection of work by Sarah Haenn 16 TX (bottom photos). “There is extraordinary energy in this room,” Hagan says with appreciation as he turns to take it all in. “The scale of your ambition is huge.”

Haenn explains that she started her stunning weavings by referencing paintings of poppies and colored them in part with magic markers. Assistant Professor Susan Sklarek MFA 77 SC describes the work as “a real feat” and adds, “The colors and striping are so beautiful.”

caption:
When grad student Soe Yu Nwe MFA 15 CR presented her latest pieces of ceramics at a crit last week, it was clear that she has hit her stride. Her breathtaking new body of work includes recent experiments with organic materials cast in glass – snake bones, a rose, a lock of her own hair – along with porcelain she saggar-fires with wood chips to create a range of gradated grays. The work “explores interiority as a feminine aesthetic,” the artist explains.

“It’s all in the air – visual depth, clarity and simplicity,” exclaims Professor Larry Bush (shown with Nwe in the top photo). 

The second-year grad student also showed intricate, layered drawings; a visual poem made of branch-like porcelain sticks (bottom photo) and dense porcelain sculpture (top photo).

“There’s a lot of fire in this work,” notes Associate Professor and Department Head Katy Schimert. “You’ve begun developing a new language.”

caption: On December 7 RISD NorCal brought back its ever-popular Holiday Sale at SHARED, an office and workspace run by Marilyn Yu 97 SC.  Club leader Heather Phillips MFA 10 GD and Melissa Small MFA 09 GD joined Yu in organizing the full-day sale, producing a show featuring work by 12 local alumni. The festive event also included fresh-baked cookies, a table for making holiday cards and writing letters to Santa and an arrangement of tempting RISD items as thank yous for donations to the club, which went to support local events and activities.

caption:
In the spirit of the holidays, RISD’s offices of Alumni Relations, Institutional Engagement, Media and the Career Center came together to adopt a family of eight through Providence’s Children’s Friend – as part of their fourth annual Spirit of Giving Holiday Drive. The nine bags of goods and more than $250 in gift cards collected went to a family of six siblings being adopted by foster parents, one of whom recently lost her job. 

Though this year’s drive ended today, for future reference you may want to find out about donating or adopting your own family at the Children’s Friend site.

caption:
Last Thursday a team of five students deftly assembled a grid of photovoltaic panels designed to soak up sun on the top of RISD’s Industrial Design Building at 161 South Main Street. To make sure the pieces didn’t blow away in the wind, the group mounted heavy ballasts to the energy-efficient installation (pictured in top photo).

The project was unveiled at the final critique for The Energy Studio, an interdisciplinary course in which 12 seniors in ID worked with three Brown Engineering majors doing research, experimenting with materials and developing presentations that effectively outline their proposals for energy innovation.

“Next semester students will build an even stronger version of this prototype,” explains Senior Critic Michael Lye 96 ID, a longtime faculty member who initiated the course almost eight years ago. “We’re hoping to permanently mount [a solar panel] to the roof. It would be a great learning tool.”

Gigi Boni, a senior at Brown, and Paul Bird 15 ID  (pictured in bottom photo) also presented E'Block, an ingenious device that attaches to power cords of common household items that rely on electricity, including laptop chargers, computers, ovens and refrigerators. The technology tracks the amount of energy consumed and sends daily reports to an online site. 

“It’s a tool to make people more aware of how much energy is consumed by different household gadgets,” explains Boni. “We imagine large companies or academic institutions would be interested in [this concept].”

To make sure the pieces didn’t blow away in the wind, the group mounted heavy ballasts to the energy-efficient installation (pictured in top photo).

The project was unveiled at the final critique for The Energy Studio, an interdisciplinary course in which 12 seniors in ID worked with three Brown Engineering majors doing research, experimenting with materials and developing presentations that effectively outline their proposals for energy innovation.

“Next semester students will build an even stronger version of this prototype,” explains Senior Critic Michael Lye 96 ID, a longtime faculty member who initiated the course almost eight years ago. “We’re hoping to permanently mount [a solar panel] to the roof. It would be a great learning tool.”

Gigi Boni, a senior at Brown, and Paul Bird 15 ID  (pictured in bottom photo) also presented E'Block, an ingenious device that attaches to power cords of common household items that rely on electricity, including laptop chargers, computers, ovens and refrigerators. The technology tracks the amount of energy consumed and sends daily reports to an online site. 

“It’s a tool to make people more aware of how much energy is consumed by different household gadgets,” explains Boni. “We imagine large companies or academic institutions would be interested in [this concept].”

caption:
In making Teddy Bear Notions, Rene Galvan MFA 15 JM salvaged pieces of transparent acrylic, c-clamps and fabric scraps from a cuddly stuffed animal, assembling them into the curious piece (fourth photo from top) now on view in Mettle. The show, which continues through December 7 at the Sol Koffler Graduate Student Gallery, challenges the functional, formal and conceptual understanding of jewelry.

“The thread joining all of the exhibited work is the critical engagement the artists have with the body – a site that is intimate, gendered and a condition of the work,” reads the artists’ statement on the gallery wall. “Mettle-ing with jewelry reconsiders the art experience as a shared activity between the artist and audience.”

At the opening reception last Thursday night, visitors gathered around a fragile pendant that Emily Grego MFA 16 JM made using thread and various dried plants. Viewers also gravitated towards a sculptural piece by Jisoo Lee MFA 16 JM made of silver, bronze and copper.

caption:
Toward the end of Friday’s Senior Open Studios, Anthony Dahut 14 FD (top photo) made a much-anticipated announcement to the crowd of students gathered in the top floor of RISD’s Furniture Design wood studio. “We have a winner!” he shouted into a microphone. “Now come claim your special treasures.”

Dahut was giving away a most adorable raffle prize: a large vase filled with 1,369 tiny cut glass terriers made by Swarovski. According to students, the Austrian jewelry company sponsored a design studio years ago and gave away product samples. Wearing a huge smile, a graphic design major snagged her glittering trinkets. 

On Thursday and Friday, students in each of the 16 undergraduate departments gave tours of their studios to members of the larger RISD community. According to upperclassmen, Foundation Studies students often attend the celebratory events to get an up-close look at their peers’ most refined work. “It helps first-year students make a final decision on which major to declare,” explained Matthew Tso 14 FD. “Our [Furniture Design] studios are always packed with visitors.”

Noelle Antignano 15 FD presented a lightweight bamboo box that currently houses her eyeglasses (bottom photo). She used a vacuum to bend the brittle wood into a boxy shape. “I wanted to play around with this material – especially because my fellow students and professors didn’t have an intimate understanding of its capabilities,” she noted. “I’d like to continue testing its durability.”

In another corner of the studio, Tso showed off rough plans to make office chairs that would play music to increase a user’s productivity. “I’m interested in the connections between fine art and wearable technology,” he noted. “It’s a brave new world for design.”

caption:
Ripping open a large cardboard box, Julia Samuels MFA 15 PR is thrilled to find a bundle of useful goodies: antique picture frames sent from a dealer in California. The printmaker uses one of the wooden treasures to cast a concrete frame for Greetings from Tchoupitoulas St., a woodcut that looks at nature’s inability to be confined (third row).

“I really like the hardness of the cement [frame],” Samuels noted at last week’s opening reception for the Printmaking Departmental Exhibition on view through Sunday, November 16 at Woods-Gerry Gallery. “The material creates tension – especially because the print is about wildlife breaking out of boundaries.”

Viewers at the opening also sized up Charta Exiccatae: Nyssa, a photo-lithography by M. Benjamin Herndon MFA 16 PT (fourth row, left photo). The artist got inspired to make the piece after close examination of the physical properties of bark. Visitors were also enamored with June: Training a Passion Vine, an ornate engraving printed on glazed earthenware by Professor of Printmaking Andrew Raftery.

caption:
Crouched low on the concrete floor of RISD’s foundry, Amy Rubinstein 17 SC (middle left photo) slams her welding helmet shut and fires up an acetaline torch. With quick motions, the sophomore attaches twisted steel rods to the bottom of a sculpture lined with serrated metal plates. As a last step, she attaches a sturdy ring to the side of the sharp installation.

“I needed a way to secure this piece to the ground,” she explains while wiping away a dark smudge on her face. “After I’m done, it will be connected to five other metal works outside the studio.”

As part of last Saturday's Open Studios – a highlight of RISD by Design weekend – Rubinstein hosted a live demo with a small team of Sculpture majors hunkered in the Metcalf Building. As punchy rock music reverberated off the foundry walls, visiting families watched the group make heavy pieces inspired by the French surrealist game Exquisite Corpse. 

“The students don’t have a lot of time to waste,” explains Sculpture Critic Chris Sancomb 93 SC, who organized the fast-paced project. “Because there’s a strict deadline, they’re forced to work intuitively and follow their gut. This mode of working can break old patterns of thinking – and it’s exciting to build in this wild atmosphere.”

In a corner of the foundry, Allison Baker MFA SC 15 (bottom photo) cranks out a human-sized heron flanked with curled slats shaped like feathers. Mark Desantis 16 SC also remains focused as he makes an installation using long, spiky poles. The oddly beautiful creations are now linked together in the small passageway behind the Metcalf Building.

“It’s really satisfying to make something for the sheer fun of it,” notes Desantis while measuring a length of rebar. “It’s a total rush.”

caption:
RISD by Design weekend kicked off last Friday with the fourth annual Pumpkinpalooza, a Staff Council event that raises spirits as well as money for two $500 student scholarships awarded each year to help seniors purchase needed art supplies. The festivities include a bake sale, raffle, games and live music performed by staff and students.

St. Louis residents Andrea and Pat Gant – who were visiting their son Will, a junior in Architecture – were happy to soak up some sun in Market Square and get a taste of the RISD experience. “You can really get a sense of the school during parents’ weekend,” said Andrea. “We’re planning to do some classroom visits and may check out the glass-blowing demonstration as well.”

Sophomore Rae Whitley 17 IL picked up some pumpkins to surprise her nine-year-old brother, who was visiting from Connecticut. “He’s going to hang out with me while my parents go to some of the RbD events,” she said. “I told him to be sure to bring his sketchbook.”

caption:
Taking a short break from socializing with his peers in the Waterman Gallery, Dirk Peteruson 16 PT walks over to inspect Fish and Coral Reef, a jacquard wall tapestry Hyunah Yong 15 TX made based on the spectacular patterns of ocean organisms.

“I feel like this fabric captures the essence of the 1960s. There are so many trippy patterns here,” the Painting major explains as he examines the mustard-colored cloth hanging from the ceiling. “It’s very psychedelic.”

The eye-catching tapestry is part of Pattern, Structure and Form, a brilliant show of woven, printed and knitted artwork by Textiles majors. Exploring the concepts of habitat, behavior and appearance in the natural world, the exhibition opened last Thursday and continues through this Friday.

On another side of the gallery, Annie Irwin 15 TX presents Fragile, Formidable, a set of handwoven samples she made using a Dobby loom. The artist created the assortment of multilayered swatches after researching the physical traits of the northern flicker bird.

“It took a while to master the Dobby loom’s computer programs,” Irwin explains while assessing her assortment of swatches. “But I was quite pleased with the outcome. As you can see, the mechanical loom has the capability to create raised structural patterns.”

In a quiet corner of the gallery, visitors also hoveredby Hummingbirds, a collection of neon-hued textiles (second from top). Amelia Solano 16 TX spun the cottony pieces in response to the crazy way the small creatures flap their wings – fluttering at about 50 times per second – to remain in flight.

Others mulled over Message from Lonesome George, a tapestry by Mint Pitaksuteephong 16 TX. The artist got the idea for the piece after learning about the steady decline – and eventual extinction – of the tortoise population in the Galapagos Islands.

Taking a short break from socializing with his peers in the Waterman Gallery, Dirk Peteruson 16 PT walks over to inspect Fish and Coral Reef, a jacquard wall tapestry Hyunah Yong 15 TX made based on the spectacular patterns of ocean organisms.

“I feel like this fabric captures the essence of the 1960s. There are so many trippy patterns here,” the Painting major explains as he examines the mustard-colored cloth hanging from the ceiling. “It’s very psychedelic.”

The eye-catching tapestry is part of Pattern, Structure and Form, a brilliant show of woven, printed and knitted artwork by Textiles majors. Exploring the concepts of habitat, behavior and appearance in the natural world, the exhibition opened last Thursday and continues through this Friday.

On another side of the gallery, Annie Irwin 15 TX presents Fragile, Formidable, a set of handwoven samples she made using a Dobby loom. The artist created the assortment of multilayered swatches after researching the physical traits of the northern flicker bird.

“It took a while to master the Dobby loom’s computer programs,” Irwin explains while assessing her assortment of swatches. “But I was quite pleased with the outcome. As you can see, the mechanical loom has the capability to create raised structural patterns.”

In a quiet corner of the gallery, visitors also hoveredby Hummingbirds, a collection of neon-hued textiles (second from top). Amelia Solano 16 TX spun the cottony pieces in response to the crazy way the small creatures flap their wings – fluttering at about 50 times per second – to remain in flight.

Others mulled over Message from Lonesome George, a tapestry by Mint Pitaksuteephong 16 TX. The artist got the idea for the piece after learning about the steady decline – and eventual extinction – of the tortoise population in the Galapagos Islands.

Amelia Solano 16 TX made Hummingbirds, eye-catching pieces that explore the relationship between birds and their environment.
Pattern, Structure and Form, a brilliant show of woven, printed and knitted artworks, is now on view in RISD's Waterman Gallery.
Annie Irwin 15 TX made these structural swatches on a Dobby loom.
The Textiles show runs through Friday, Sept. 19, in the Waterman Gallery.

caption:
Cheyenne Julien 16 PT still remembers the nights when her father quietly fumed at the dinner table after another incident with the neighborhood cops patrolling her Bronx neighborhood. The police routinely detained the African American man, asking questions and searching for illegal weapons or drugs. 

“It was harassment. Those police officers didn’t have a reason to stop my father,” the Painting major notes while fighting back tears. “He was just trying to get home after a long day at work.” 

Holding a sign reading “Black Lives Matter,” Julien was just one of approximately 200 RISD and Brown students who gathered in Market Square last Friday evening to silently protest against police mishandling of people of color. According to event organizer Yelitsa Jean-Charles 16 IL, the recent shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown in Ferguson, MO was one of the catalysts for the peaceful demonstration. Many of the activists who showed support are involved in Brown’s chapter of the NAACP.

“These horrible events raise important questions related to racial profiling and discrimination, and also shine light on the militarization of our police forces,” says Jean-Charles, president of RISD student org Black Artists and Designers (BAAD). “Why is it that officers are able to whip out deadly equipment against unarmed people? We’re here to raise awareness and empower people to start a movement against police brutality.”

Early on in the protest, Moriah Benton 16 IL, president of RISD Feminists, jumped to the front of the crowd with a bullhorn and urged her peers to use their mobile phones and cameras to document illegal acts of police brutality. “Record what you see. Don’t look away,” she shouted. “We need to be vigilant in protecting our civil rights.” 

Inspired by Keith Wallace, an artist who lay down in Philadelphia’s Love Park wearing a bloodied t-shirt to protest Brown’s death, the protestors moved to the center of the square and lay down close together (top photo). One of the event organizers then read the names of roughly 30 young people of color who have been killed recently by law enforcement officers.

“Witnesses said it was shocking to see still bodies taking up that amount of space in Market Square – a historical place where slaves were once bought and sold,” notes Jean-Charles. “It was an emotional visual.”

Danielle Glynn 16 FAV holds up a sign reading "Black Lives Matter."
According to event organizer Yelitsa Jean-Charles 16 IL, the brutal shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown in Ferguson, MO and other tragic minority deaths was the catalyst for the demonstration.

caption:
RISD alumni from MA and RI met in Cape Cod on Sunday for a visit to the famed Edward Gorey House Museum. A collaboration between the RI and MA alumni clubs and local children’s book illustrators, the trip was a great chance to tour the unique museum and celebrate the works of writer and artist, Edward Gorey.

While taking a closer look at Gorey’s cautionary tales, alphabet books, and fictionalized memoires, attendees participated in the museum’s whimsical scavenger hunt, searching amongst the impressive collection of Gorey’s beloved treasures and relics.

Event coordinator Christina Rodriguez [03 IL] used ticket sales to raise money for the Animal Rescue League of Brewster, a cause that was close to Gorey’s own animal-loving heart. Following the tour, attendees met at the home of RISD-friend Jason Hart for a tasty end-of-summer potluck.

Thanks to all the attendees who made this event a success! Keep an eye out for more alumni events in New England this fall!

caption:
The Met – RISD’s biggest and busiest dining hall – has a new look. Just in time for the start of school, crews finished installing long, family-style tables so that students can chat more easily while enjoying the good food made by RISD chefs.

To add fun pops of color to the spacious hall, Director of Retail and Dining Virginia Dunleavy snapped up some vintage chairs at a Massachusetts antiques fair. The summer redesign includes a new lounge area in a corner of the facility, where students now have the option of socializing on lush sofas while catching the headlines on a giant, wall-mounted TV.

In addition, The Met has added a new salad bar and a special refrigerated section for gluten-free foods. “It’s like a New York restaurant has opened on campus,” notes Admissions Officer Antonio Peters 04 IL, who has been coming here since he was a student a decade ago. “This place feels modern and sleek. Students are already loving it.”

caption: Providence-based jewelry maker Priya Himatsingka 00 JM has launched an updated website to promote her sizable collection of elegant, handmade pieces made of silver, high-karat gold and diamonds. Born in India to a family of textile designers, Hamatsingka studied at Parsons and NYU before coming to RISD. Her beautifully understated necklaces, bracelets, earrings and rings are available online, through wholesale distribution and at scores of stores throughout the country.

caption:
Standing in the center of Woods-Gerry Gallery, David Harrison took a quiet moment to size up What’s Left Behind, a rust-stained garment adorned with large metal nails. Pre-College student Gillian Yerington made the piece during the intensive intro to college-level studio work she has been experiencing this summer at RISD.

“It would be completely impractical to wear this,” notes Harrison. “There’s a real possibility you could get slightly impaled if you bumped against the hardware. But it’s totally inspiring to see how the artist went about making it. It’s really powerful.”

The sharply designed textile is on view through tomorrow, August 8, in the Pre-College Exhibition, a collection of engaging works made by teenage artists enrolled in the six-week program. On Wednesday evening, hundreds of students celebrated the show of their final projects at a bustling opening reception.

Harrison (pictured above) also debuted his own textile imprinted with a grid of graphics based on US license plates. “The owners of a diner in my hometown strung up funny vanity plates to a wall,” explains the native of Exeter, NH. “That image has always stayed with me. I thought it would be an interesting visual pattern to silkscreen.”

While taking a break from welding in RISD’s metal shop to visit the show, Amy Lubinstein 17 SC was immediately taken with Letters, a statuesque mannequin made of delicate paper (to the left in the second row above). Cyrus Glanzer made the arresting piece while studying Sculpture this summer with faculty member Lu Heintz 01 SC.

“I’m drawn to the sheer size of this paper doll,” explains Lubinstein. “And the texture of the layered paper is just elegantly beautiful.”

If you’re on campus, act fast! The exhibition at Woods-Gerry closes on Friday, August 8.

photos.caption: A collection of engaging works made by high school students enrolled in RISD’s Pre-College Program is now on view in Woods-Gerry Gallery.
Cyrus Glanzer made Letters, a statuesque mannequin constructed out of delicate paper.
David Harrison, a high school student from New Hampshire, shows off his own textile imprinted with a grid of graphics that take the form of US license plates.
Valentine Thayer made Gekka while studying Industrial Design.
Katherine Pack created Organic Perpetuation, a beautifully glazed ceramics piece.

caption:
On Friday June 27th the Northern California Alumni Chapter came together for the opening reception of First/Last, a RISD Alumni show at Park Life Gallery in San Francisco.

First/Last highlights each artist’s unique process, and points that define it—from the first moment of inspiration, the journey of making, up until the last moment, when the piece is deemed complete.

The show will be on display at Park Life Gallery from June 27–July 27 2014.

Featured Alumni:

Jonathan Anzalone (BFA Painting ‘03) 

Raïssa Bump (BFA Jewelry ‘03)

Lara Cannon (BFA Illustration ‘06)

Percy Cannon (BFA Painting ‘06)

Lizzy Cross (BFA Painting ‘04)

caption:
“RISD’s Industrial Design program shaped my approach to making stuff,” says Providence-based electric guitar builder Jason Lee 10 ID. “It’s not just product design but problem solving. And building a custom instrument for a client is also about problem solving and being sensitive to human factors.”

Lee first got  bitten by the lutherie bug as a senior at RISD when he took a guitar-building class with Nick Holcomb 08 SC, who runs his own successful guitar and bass business in Rhode Island. After working with Holcomb for about a year after graduation, he started building guitars under his own name in a shared space in Providence’s Keeseh Woodshop.

Lee has completed eight instruments to date and says that he’s learning so much that each new guitar he builds is his best. He favors walnut and maple and using a hand-rubbed oil finish on his instruments and hopes to continue honing his technique and building his reputation in the coming years.

caption:
Charlotte Potter: Fragile Cartography, a solo show of new and recent work by Charlotte Potter MFA 10 GL, is on view at Tidewater Community College’s Visual Arts Center in Portsmouth, VA from July 4 through August 28. The exhibition includes glass and new media pieces that explore notions of love, loss and the basic human desire for connection.

Life-size figurative glass armor made up of more than 4,000 glass microscope slides of the artist’s skin (top photos) illustrates a reluctance to expose ourselves to others. Charlotte’s Web (bottom photos) ­– a network of hand-engraved glass cameos of Potter’s 800-plus Facebook friends – examines familiarity, intimacy and the online persona.

“In my studio practice, I struggle with duality,” says Potter, who manages the glass studio at the Chrysler Museum of Art in Norfolk, VA. “Glass encapsulates binary qualities cloaked with competing characteristics: liquid and solid, elastic and brittle, captivating and humbling. My work pays homage to traditional glass techniques, or industries that have used glass, which I refashion to create commentary on our present moment in time.”

Potter will give a gallery talk at the Visual Arts Center as part of the opening reception on July 10.

caption:
For years homeowners David Conrath MID 85 and Deena Stone 85 TX have been piquing the curiosity of their neighbors in the Del Ray section of Alexandria, VA. Their Craftsman-style cottage and mid-century modern addition sits on the same site as a super-cool (and soon-to-be-restored) Airstream parked out back. Architects and décor aficionados alike recently got a closer look at the tidy residence as part of the 2014 Del Ray House and Garden Tour (with virtual access via a series of posts on the related blog DIY Del Ray).

Conrath and Stone renovated the house themselves and are proud of its net-zero energy construction and dual rooftop gardens. Visitors were suitably impressed with their efforts to replicate the materials and methods used in the original 1920s construction and their selection of nifty antique furnishings.

Click on the photos above for caption information.

Vintage chic.

caption:
Providence-based artist Esther Solondz MFA 80 PH has long studied transformative materials in her work. In Rust Heads (2007–08) she used iron filings and salt to create haunting portraits in rust. With Salt Work (2004) she took advantage of the natural properties of salt, growing massive sculptures reminiscent of stalactites and other natural formations.

“I work with salt, water and other mundane materials like soap, mud and seeds that we encounter in our daily lives,” the artist says. She prefers “materials that make miraculous transformations when they change from one state to another or when they interact with other materials.”

Now Solondz has stepped out of the studio to create a public installation (funded in part by the RI State Council on the Arts) in Providence’s Lippitt Memorial Park. The Hummingbird Palace – a 15-foot structure made of welded steel, threadline, silicon, epoxy and urethane ­– opens tomorrow (Friday, June 27) at 4 pm. The piece is made to evolve over time, with flowering vines growing through its intricate sugary structure and feeders designed to attract hummingbirds.

Click on images above for caption information.

caption:
Last Thursday evening, visitors to the RISD Museum got an earful of The Mighty Good Boys, a rip-roaring rockabilly band with heavy Appalachian folk influences. The band’s uptempo harmonica riffs and lively bass lines set the tone for Design the Night: KNOW HOW, which invited the public to enjoy artist demos, peruse ancient artifacts – and even participate in a live recording session.

The event marked the opening of the newly renovated sixth-floor galleries for ancient Egyptian and Asian art, along with the new Angelo Donghia Costume and Textiles Gallery and Study Center. In a brightly lit hallway, families stood transfixed as they watched members of local arts nonprofit AS220 replicate treasured objects from the collection using a 3D printer. Nearby, others happily explored the new study space available to RISD students and others interested in further exploring the Costume and Textiles Collection.

Alyssa Carroll, a rising junior attending the University of Rhode Island, was thrilled to get an exclusive look at Nesmin, RISD’s resident mummy (dating from 250 BCE). Curator of Ancient Art Gina Borromeo and Emily Russo, a Brown PhD candidate in Egyptology, gave a candid talk on the history of  the beloved artifact. “It’s such fun to be at the museum tonight,” noted Carroll. “I couldn’t think of anywhere else I’d rather be!”

To read more about the museum’s renovated galleries and related shows, check out this news story on risd.edu.

caption:
The Environmental Design Research Association recently recognized GA Collaborative’s Masoro Village Project in Rwanda with a Great Places Award. The community-led initiative to construct 50 environmentally friendly residential buildings using locally sourced EarthBags got underway last summer with the completion of the first unit.

As GA Collaborative cofounder and Interior Architecture Critic Michael Beaman reports, the community has also launched a partnership with Kate Spade in New York City that will provide sustainable income for Masoro artisans, who will create handbags and other accessories for sale in the US and Europe. Alumni Yutaka Sho BLA 96 and Zaneta Hong 02 ID are also fully engaged in the nonprofit’s ongoing efforts in Rwanda.

“At the core of GA Collaborative’s mission is the idea that all have the right to benefit from design,” says Beaman. “We also worked with villagers to leverage local weaving techniques to create design solutions at an architectural scale.” 

Key to how the Collaborative operates is a commitment “to engaging the community in the process, not just building something and leaving,” Beaman adds. “Ideally we want to erase ourselves from the equation so that construction continues after we leave.”

Click on the photos above for caption information.

Click on the photos above for caption information.

photos.caption: The first EarthBag house close to completion. Local artisans created woven screens that protect porches and exterior living spaces.
Masoro artisans at work creating handbags and other handcrafted accessories for Kate Spade.
Kate Spade built secure workshops for artisans in Masoro.
Villagers worked with architecture students from the nearby Kigali Institute of Science & Technology.
Moveable, hand-woven screens provide privacy while allowing for airflow.

caption: At RISD’s Commencement ceremony on May 31 architect and social justice advocate Hildegard Vásquez BArch 94 was given the2014 Alumni Award for Professional Achievement. RISD’s Alumni Council had the pleasure of hosting Hildegard for dinner that night, and enjoyed a presentation on the amazing work she is doing in Panama.  The Council was lucky enough to be joined by last year’s awardee Tamara Kaplan MA/MAT 00 as well as incoming freshman (and Hildegard’s niece) Carolina Esslinger 18!

caption:
On Sunday, April 27 RISD Cycling and the Center for Student Involvement (CSI) hosted the Eastern Collegiate Cycling Conference (ECCC) championship race. The much-anticipated event brought hundreds of adrenaline-filled athletes from more than 40 colleges to downtown Providence to compete. 

Wearing their signature hot pink outfits, RISD riders zipped around the hilly course – which wrapped around Memorial Park – to compete in heats throughout the day. After zooming across the finish line, the cyclists were greeted by cheering spectators standing next to a line of festive food trucks.

By the end of the day, there were victories to celebrate. For much of the Men Collegiate A Race, team captain Jules Goguely 14 ID was at the front of the pack until Penn State’s Greg Ratzell inched by him to take the lead and title. And Brian Hicks 16 GD won the Men Collegiate C Race in a group sprint.

Congratulations to the RISD Cycling riders!

caption:
On Friday Rhode Island Senator Sheldon Whitehouse and RISD’s interim President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID toured the Techstyle Haus in progress as students work to finalize their 2014 Solar Decathlon Europe entry. Later this month, the soft-shelled, solar-powered house will be disassembled and shipped to Versailles, France, where it will be rebuilt in time for the late-June competition.

“It’s terrific to see the house so close to being finished,” says Whitehouse. And Somerson adds, “This is what happens when you design from the inside out, when the system dictates the form, materials and construction.”

For caption information, click on each image (photos by David O’Connor).

caption:
On Monday, April 21, juniors, seniors and graduate students shared their work with representatives from more than 40 galleries, museums and arts organizations at the Career Center’s 2014 Fine Arts Portfolio Review. Given the number of participants, RISD career counselors opted to hold the review at the Rhode Island Convention Center downtown, where the hall buzzed with excitement as students sharpened their networking skills and participating fine arts professionals offered feedback and advice.

“Overall it was a terrific day and hosting the event at the Convention Center immediately elevated the quality of the experience for both reviewers and students,” notes Susan Andersen, associate director of the Career Center.

Reps eager to review RISD student work came from a wide range of organizations, including New York Foundation for the Arts, The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts, the Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, MA and New York galleries such as Mixed Greens, Luhring Augustine, Freight + Volume and Cheim & Read in NYC (owned by alumni John Cheim 77 PT and Howard Read 76 PH).

Senior Otis Gray SC 14 took advantage of the “awesome” opportunity for the third time this year and was once again floored by the experience. “I don’t think people realize how cool it is for that many amazing companies to come together in one place to give you feedback,” he says. Gray has already made plans to travel to Peru after graduation and then find a studio in Philadelphia, but he was interested to hear whether or not his portfolio seems cohesive. One of the professionals he met with was Ali Goodwin, director of Drift Gallery in Portsmouth, NH. “Ali is one of the coolest ladies ever,” Gray says seriously. “She has taken some crazy risks in life to explore her passion for art and encouraged me to travel the world. We had a really intense, inspirational talk that I’m never going to forget.”

photos by Kevin Jankowski 88 IL

caption:
RISD and Brown alumni, faculty, donors and friends got up close and personal with the Techstyle Haus last Friday evening. In addition to student-led tours, guests heard remarks from student representatives of the team from RISD, Brown and the University of Applied Sciences in Erfurt, Germany, key faculty and administrators, and lead donor Saint-Gobain. RISD President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID and Brown President Christina Paxton wielded a pair of giant scissors to officially cut the ribbon.

Students will continue work on the Haus for a few weeks before breaking it down to reassemble at the competition this summer in Versailles. Read remarks by RISD and Brown Presidents Somerson and Paxton and see more photos on the Techstyle Haus blog.

photos by Melinda Rainsberger 04 FAV

caption:
An update from our RISD Tokyo Leader, Karin Kunori 10 GD:

Many greetings from Tokyo! After a long winter, spring is finally here. In Japan, people celebrate the coming of spring with Hanami (flower viewing) when sakura (cherry blossoms) bloom all over the country. The season is brief, usually lasting just two weeks between the end of March and the beginning of April.

The Japanese word is written 花見. “花” means flower, and “見”, means observing. The Hanami custom is many centuries old, and it used to announced the start of the rice harvest season. The sakura (and traditional haiku poems about sakura) remind us to cherish each day. The short life span of the flowers, and even the beauty of the falling petals is a Japanese metaphor for life; spirited and beautiful, yet fleeting and ephemeral. 

In the modern day, Hanami commonly consists of having an outdoor party with friends and colleagues. People gather wherever sakura trees are found to hold picnics and festivals from early morning to night. 

Last weekend, some RISD TOKYO alumni got together to enjoy a Japanese Hanami picnic with many more Tokyo friends. Sitting under the sakura trees at Inokashira Park, we enjoyed good food, drink, and merry company. Inokashira Park, in west Tokyo, is famous for having over 1000 sakura trees, and a lake where people can rent boats to view the blossoms on the water’s edge. Here are several photos from our event! An afternoon of sunshine, boat riding, picnicking, sharing stories and making new friends. We wish you were here!

To connect with alumni in and around Tokyo, please join our Facebook group.

caption:
On Friday night, amped-up students were attracted to an explosion of sound and color erupting in a corner of the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery. The cause of the sonic mayhem was Stinky Nice, a rowdy noise band (pictured in top photo) formed by five mighty musical RISD students.

As lead singer Adrienne Fowler 14 FAV howled into a microphone, a saxophone player squeaked and blatted out dissonant melodies. “This is out of control!” yelled one viewer while jumping up in the air.

The crazed musical performance was part of Museum Takeover, an all-night event sponsored by RISD’s Programming Board. Prior to the opening, students installed interactive art exhibitions throughout the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery and the museum. 

Standing in front of a checkered wall, Mariam Quraishi 15 IL played a game that involved shooting moving laser targets projected on the wall. Other students had a ball using a light installation to cast shadow puppets across the Grand Gallery’s blue walls and 18th-century oil paintings. 

For caption information, click on the photos above (photos courtesy RISDKIDS).

caption:
Naked and slathered in petroleum jelly, Doreen Garner MFA 14 GL slides her body against the interior of a small glass tank stationed in the center of a Glass department studio. As a crowd forms around the visceral spectacle (pictured in top photo), she nestles into a pile of stuffed, rubber tubes that could be mistaken for intestines. 

With a stoic face, Garner beckons audience members to come close to her glass cage and then wipes her open eye against the transparent barrier. The action draws tears from both the artist and the viewers. “One girl started crying in a corner of the room,” Garner would later note. “It was an intense performance that challenged the typical power dynamic that exists between the subject and the viewer.”

This hair-raising performance was part of RISD’s Graduate Open Studios event last Friday night. Members of the public were welcome to wander through the cavernous hallways decorated with half-complete sculptures, ornate jewelry pieces and other works.

In a nearby building, students formed a line around a table holding broken objects cradled in square blocks of felt. Kate Bell MFA 14 JM used a shattered teacup and a string of pearls to create art that explores feelings of absence and yearning.

In the same room, Monica Choi MFA 14 JM presented brooches made of discarded technological devices. Memory boards and audio wires are some of her favorite things to refashion into wearable baubles. “I’m attracted to objects that were once intimately part of humans’ lives,” she noted.

For caption information, click on the photos above. And check out this video version of Garner’s intense performance!

caption:
On Thursday night, students took turns peering inside an unusual installation lined with stacks of philosophy books, an unused camera, palm leaves, FBI documents and a small Koran. Made by Andre Bradley MFA 15 PH, the thoughtful piece (third photo from top) provides an abstract sketch of his relationship to his family, masculinity and spiritual beliefs.

The installation is part of Reading Room, an exhibition on view for the rest of the semester in the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery. Curated by Seojung Min MFA 14 PR and Wangui Maina MFA 14 PR, the show includes introspective sculpture, paintings and other works directly inspired by the artists’ favorite books or snippets of text.

“The line between artist and author becomes easily blurred when considering reading as a form of exchange,” notes Maina. “The wide range of media in this exhibition emphasizes the many ways reading functions.”

For instance, Matthew Mahoney MFA 14 SC is showing a series of ink drawings that are visual interpretations of the characters featured in Cormack McCarthy’s gut-wrenching novels. On another side of the gallery, Cecile Chekovsky 15 AP presents a cotton knitwear collection made after finishing Milk, a historical novel about enslaved nursemaids.

At the opening reception, Robert Hurlbut 14 TX was drawn to bold paintings of female protagonists by Sophia Narrett MFA 14 PT. Meanwhile, Reesa Wood MFA 14 PT was busy inspecting Galveston Flood, a wall piece Lucy Humphreys 16 FD made after researching a devastating sea storm that pummeled an island off the west coast of Africa.

“It’s certainly a force to be reckoned with,” Wood notes, looking closely at the single piece of Tyvek used to make the piece. “Its material conjures up images of Haz-Mat suits and residential wreckage.”

Reading Room continues at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery though June 1.

caption:
On Wednesday Ceramics students gathered to hear visiting artist Brie Ruais speak about how she uses clay as “a stand-in for the body,” creating sculptural pieces that “assertively claim space” while transparently reflecting the gestures used to create them. She sees her sculpture, which she recently showed in a solo exhibition at Nicole Klagsbrun in New York City, as a feminist take on the work of sculptor and video artist Richard Serra. Other influences include contemporary stalwarts Jackson Pollock, Bruce Nauman and the late abstract expressionist Agnes Martin.

Ruais generally begins each piece with 130 pounds of clay (her body weight) and then spreads it upwards or outwards in a process she refers to as “physical confrontation.” When Associate Professor Katy Schimert, head of the Ceramics department, had the opportunity to see Ruais’ work in the fall, she immediately asked her to visit, describing the work as having “a monumental presence and power.”

Click on the images above for more information.

caption:
RISD/LA alumni, parents and current students welcomed interim President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID to the Annenberg Beach House on Wednesday for a reception and campus update. For New Englanders in attendance, the 60+ degree weather, and views of the palm tree-lined beach, were a welcome respite!  President Somerson shared progress on the strategic plan directives, including renovations to the ISB, the inventory results of the campus master plan, new academic initiatives, and fundraising priorities.

Photos by Emma Canfield 12 PH

caption:
The art in the senior Illustration show that just closed at Woods-Gerry Gallery conjured up memorable passages from Animal Farm, George Orwell’s famous allegorical novel. Those who attended last week’s opening were drawn to large paintings by Elise Powell 14 IL that depict crazed hens breaking out of their cages and eating their unhatched young.

“As you can see, the chickens are on strike,” explains Powell. “I was inspired by the thought of animals rebelling against their captors.”

To give the work a glossy finish, the illustrator layered quick-drying poster paints on the canvas (pictured in the top photo). “If I used an egg tempera, that would have brought the piece to a whole new level,” jokes Powell. “I wanted to experiment with modern techniques.”

Scarecrow Women, a mixed media piece by Sophie Page 14 IL, also garnered a lot of attention. The artist attached ceramic masks adorned with flower wreathes to patterned cotton dresses (bottom right).

“If you look at the faces closely enough, you can see little teeth,” notes Madeline Cann 14 JM. “They’re cute but also a little creepy. I appreciate that duality.”

caption:
RISD Tokyo recently participated in DAMNIT PARTY: Tokyo night of Art and Music, and it was a great success!  DAMNIT is a new series of DJ showcase events in Tokyo, hosted by artist-turned-DJ Katohmy Laeyn 09 IL and several talented Tokyo DJs. For the first time last Saturday, the DJs combined music with art, featuring an art gallery party to bring young creatives together. The gallery event was led by Karin Kunori 10 GD, who displayed several of her textiles, paper collage panels, and typographic posters.The casual atmosphere allowed for visitors to browse the designs and meet other young internationally minded artists.

Karin introduced her work and led an interactive art piece, where visitors were asked to share their views on “what home means to me” and add responses to a large paper collage panel. The collection of words, phrases, and thoughts was a great conversation starter and a way for visitors to enjoy the making process.

After the gallery event, the night kicked up as Katohmy Laeyn and his international group of DJs showed off their musical talents, mixing everything from indie to 90s to Nu Disco. It was a great chance to experience both the strengths of art and music.

caption:
A few weeks ago the Edna Lawrence Nature Lab provided the setting for a much-needed break to the winter doldrums. Live Animal Study paired alumni with humane educator Laurelin Sitterly 03 IL to sketch both live rescued animals and the Lab’s taxidermy specimens. This popular annual art workshop is in its 3rd year running!

Since the figure “models” were animals rescued from local shelters, workshop coordinator Christina Rodriguez 03 IL donated all proceeds from ticket sales to the RISPCA, Providence Animal Rescue League and Sweet Binks Rabbit Rescue.

For more information on this event, or to be put on the mailing list for the next workshop, please contact Christina at mail*at*christinarodriguez.com.

Since the figure "models" were animals rescued from local shelters, workshop coordinator Christina Rodriguez 03 IL donated all proceeds from ticket sales to the RISPCA, Providence Animal Rescue League and Sweet Binks Rabbit Rescue.

For more information on this event, or to be put on the mailing list for the next workshop, please contact Christina at mail*at*christinarodriguez.com.

caption:
Interim President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID hosted a lively cocktail reception at last week’s 102nd annual College Art Association (CAA) Conference in Chicago. The conference provides an important forum for visual arts professionals to exchange research, creative work, methodologies, and pedagogies. The reception provided a wonderful and much needed opportunity to catch up with other alums and RISD faculty, and network during the dog days of winter.  

Top photo: Fo Wilson 05 MFA FD, right

caption:
Students in Creature-Creation – a Wintersession course offered by Film/Animation/Video and Big Nazo Lab – know how to leave their inhibitions at the door. On a chilly afternoon in February, the group of artists left studio to film spontaneous meetings with the public while disguised in breathable helmets designed for robotic extraterrestrials.

For some, the costumes brought out wild tendencies. Mariah Robinson 17 FS scaled a corporate high-rise in Providence’s financial district after becoming bored with cycling through the building’s revolving doors. Arielle Haskell 17 FS and Tessa Magliano 17 FS jumped into dumpsters to cap off a day of dancing on stoops and street corners. “Everyone was staring at us,” Magliano says. “But we were in costume so we weren’t embarrassed. It was silly fun.”

FAV faculty member Erminio Pinque 83 IL taught students how to make their attention-grabbing puppet costumes in Big Nazo Lab, his renowned creature-building workshop that produces completely wild sculptural masks and costumes worn by members of an international performance troupe. The students’ hilarious videos will be included in the annual Creature-Creation Show, which will be held on March 1 and 2 in the RISD Auditorium.

To read more about students’ puppet making techniques and their outlandish experiences roaming the streets of downtown Providence, check out this news story on risd.edu!

caption:
An architectural rendering that reroutes foot traffic in an African capital; a metal installation visualizing the rhythm of the human heart; and a multimedia piece focused on Toyko’s sizzling energy are just some of the fascinating projects featured in the 2014 Architecture Triennial, a comprehensive exhibition that closes this evening at Woods-Gerry Gallery.

The triennial is on view in conjunction with a visit from members of the National Architectural Accreditation Board, a team of professionals charged with reviewing the Architecture department’s curriculum, facilities, administrative processes and student support.

Among its priorities, Architecture at RISD emphasizes the importance of design for the public good. For instance, in the Wintersession studio Urban Interventions, Zachary Futterer MArch 14 was one of more than a dozen students who worked to breathe new life into Providence’s inner city Grace Church cemetery (see rendering above). “This [project] provides opportunities to improve foot traffic, social interaction, visual beauty, street safety and a sense of ownership,” Futterer notes in his artist statement. “On a deeper level, the repurposing of the cemetery will use the theme of mortality to encourage locals to consider their own legacy and contributions to the neighborhood.”

Fisiha Likke MArch 14 presents Disappearing Spaces, a project that reimagines the urban landscape of Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia. “I’d like to use green spaces to connect the social fabric of the city,” he notes.

Join Architecture students and faculty for the closing reception this evening (Sunday, February 16) from 6–7:30 pm.

caption:
At the end of Wintersession last week students in RISD’s first theatrical design studio – co-taught by Sculpture Critic Jane South and Interior Architecture Critic Michael McGarty – gave visitors a backstage peek inside The Magic Box, an all-new ballet that will premiere this spring in Providence. As part of RISD’s newly launched Robert L. Turner Theatrical and Performance Design initiative, students collaborated with the Providence Ballet Theatre company to design sets and costumes that support the larger vision of the piece. During the performances in April, dancers will engage with the student-designed set pieces (shown above) and wear costumes inspired by Greek mythology as the ballet’s main character struggles to resolve his inner conflict and reach enlightenment.

For more information on the collaboration, see Making Magic on the risd.edu site.

caption:
A pristine blanket of snow added to the eerily beautiful aura students created at Providence’s Grace Church Cemetery last weekend. Called SouthLight, their temporary installation was the culmination of Elettra Bordonaro’s Urban Interventions Wintersession studio.

Neighbors, community activists and artists alike heeded the visiting artist’s instructions to “follow the light” through the 1850s-era cemetery, stopping to read highlighted headstones (including those of fallen World War II fighter pilot William Armstrong and African-American opera singer Sissieretta Jones) and to gaze up at the beautifully blue-lit branches of the trees.

Visitors were welcomed into the historic cemetery gatehouse for hot cocoa and coffee and invited to share their ideas for how to permanently improve the site. “We live across the street and would love to grow flowers inside the cemetery gates,” one young couple offered. Members of Stop Wasting Abandoned Property (SWAP) – a local nonprofit that has developed multiple properties in the neighborhood – are hoping that the weekend installation will draw attention to the site and reinvigorate their plan to form a neighborhood committee to keep the cemetery safe and clean.

caption:
In the entryway of Brown’s Granoff Center for the Creative Arts, a student wearing a pink-hued body suit sits cross-legged on a large scroll of paper. Every few minutes, she stands up to give onlookers a good look at the graphic images of human organs and mechanical symbols printed on her skin-tight outfit. Youbin Kang 14 TX created the performance art piece (pictured in the top photo) in response to inhumane conditions some factory workers in third world countries are forced to endure.

The powerful piece was just one small part of Don’t Be a Stranger, the sixth annual Brown/RISD dual degree exhibition that focuses on themes of neighborliness, proximity and foreign belonging. At Thursday’s opening reception, students inspected the interactive art pieces while playing miniature golf, among other backyard games.

Adventurous visitors to the show couldn’t help but literally climb into Mother Said to Never Put Your Head in a Trash Bag, a hanging installation made out of plastic sheeting, wire and an electric fan (pictured second photo from top). Others formed a line to gain entry to a rowdy dinner party held off the art center’s main stairwell. Felipe Di Poi 17 FAV, Nikolas Bentel 17 ID, Amy Chen 17 TX and Nellie Robinson 17 IL allowed new guests into the charming event every two minutes.

Don’t fret if you missed the opening. Don’t Be a Stranger will be on view through February 12 in Brown’s Granoff Center for the Creative Arts!

caption:
An architectural installation that enhances the functionality of a hurricane barrier. Ceramic cups inspired by the unique irregularities found on orange skins. Lightweight garments inspired by grids seen in urban landscapes. 

All of these projects are  on view in a brilliant new exhibition featuring work by graduate students in RISD’s Interior Architecture department. “Because we work across disciplines, we wanted to show the versatility of our studies,” explains Colin Stief MA 14, who helped curate the exhibition. “We also wanted to create a dialogue about the importance of adaptive reuse versus new construction.”

At Thursday’s opening reception in the Sol Koffler Graduate Student Gallery, visitors lingered around a model building constructed by Sarah Reilly MDes 14 (pictured above). The graduate student developed a theoretical project that revitalizes a dilapidated factory in Boston’s South End. In her proposal, translucent openings run from the building’s roof to the bottom level, allowing natural light to enter the space. She proposes a tattoo parlor on the ground floor.

Protective Garment, a wearable paper model (bottom photo), also attracted attention. Mark Larson, a Brown graduate student in Theatre Arts and Performance Studies, noted that the piece appears round from afar but is actually spiky to touch. Sally Gates MDes 14, Geonwoo Nam MDes 14 and Ziwei Zhang MDes 14 designed the piece to shield the human body while simultaneously camouflaging its form.

Onlookers were also mesmerized by a video documenting an adaptive reuse project completed by students in the fall Intro to Design Studio II taught by Assistant Professor Yugon Kim. The designers found creatively sustainable ways to renovate the inside of Second Life, the student-run materials resource center downtown.

Be sure to check out the Interior Architecture graduate student exhibition before it closes on February 9!
