In her proposal, translucent openings run from the building’s roof to the bottom level, allowing natural light to enter the space. She proposes a tattoo parlor on the ground floor.

Protective Garment, a wearable paper model (bottom photo), also attracted attention. Mark Larson, a Brown graduate student in Theatre Arts and Performance Studies, noted that the piece appears round from afar but is actually spiky to touch. Sally Gates MDes 14, Geonwoo Nam MDes 14 and Ziwei Zhang MDes 14 designed the piece to shield the human body while simultaneously camouflaging its form.

Onlookers were also mesmerized by a video documenting an adaptive reuse project completed by students in the fall Intro to Design Studio II taught by Assistant Professor Yugon Kim. The designers found creatively sustainable ways to renovate the inside of Second Life, the student-run materials resource center downtown.

Be sure to check out the Interior Architecture graduate student exhibition before it closes on February 9!
trail.content_raw:
An architectural installation that enhances the functionality of a hurricane barrier. Ceramic cups inspired by the unique irregularities found on orange skins. Lightweight garments inspired by grids seen in urban landscapes. 

All of these projects are  on view in a brilliant new exhibition featuring work by graduate students in RISD’s Interior Architecture department. “Because we work across disciplines, we wanted to show the versatility of our studies,” explains Colin Stief MA 14, who helped curate the exhibition. "We also wanted to create a dialogue about the importance of adaptive reuse versus new construction.”

At Thursday's opening reception in the Sol Koffler Graduate Student Gallery, visitors lingered around a model building constructed by Sarah Reilly MDes 14 (pictured above). caption:
Wrapped from head to toe in a thick sheath of soft fabric, Julia Little 14 TX shuffles her way into the center of a small group of students and faculty gathered in College Building for a critique last Friday. The Textiles major is modeling brilliantly colored fabrics designed by Amy Chiao 14 TX.

“The shapes are so unusual,” notes Interim Dean of Fine Arts Anais Missakian 84 TX. “I love how these [textiles] play with space and light.” 

Always in a constant state of experimentation, Chiao weaves fabrics (using the computer program WeavePoint) to make avant-garde costumes. “I’m really interested in performance art,” she explains. “I like seeing how my garments constrict the body.”

Down the hall, Susan Williams 14 TX presents a collection of stretchy textile swatches made of elastic threads and monofilament. The senior imagines that the pliable fabrics could be fashioned into bulky sweaters or unusual jackets.

The designer also showcases large swaths of woven cloth meant for interior decoration. Professor Emeritus Lorraine Howes, former head of Apparel Design, is especially impressed with an elegant, gray-toned wall tapestry made on a Jacquard loom and inspired by grid patterns found in urban landscapes.

“I started noticing that grates and fences –  structural objects in cities – are never perfectly lined up,” Willliams notes. “I’m interested in those breaks in symmetry.”

caption:
A message from RISD/LA co-leaders Liz Lanphear 04 FAV and Marisa Murrow 00 IL:

On December 7 our group gathered to welcome the holiday season at the cozy house of Scott Waterman 80 PT.  We listened to rockin’ tunes, made ornaments from his scrap art paper, caught up with old friends and made some new ones.  Many many thanks to Scott and Brett for their generosity in welcoming us into their home, and also to the attending alums for their hard work in making unique decorations.  Our creations will be hung in housing for formerly homeless families in Los Angeles– the Midnight Mission Transitional Apartment Complex in Inglewood.

Any alumni interested in volunteering to decorate the Complex on December 14th, at noon, can contact us on Facebook through the RISD/LA Group Events page.

Happy Holidays Alums!

caption:
At their end-of-semester crit yesterday, students in Associate Professor Jonathan Knowles’ advanced Architecture studio presented an update on the Techstyle Haus they’re designing for the 2014 Solar Decathlon Europe competition in Versailles, France. The overall shape of the house – the exterior of which will be made of woven fiberglass – has changed in recent months, and students are getting closer to finalizing designs on everything from lighting and power to water treatment systems to interior room dividers and textile wall coverings.  

The critics present for the session, including Dean of Architecture + Design Pradeep Sharma and Interim Dean of Fine Arts Anais Missakian, took part in a wide-ranging discussion that included questions about the mass of the structure; its ability to withstand wind, tension and uplift; the gutter system under development; and the plan of attack for actually assembling the prototype on site – as a fully functional house – prior to the competition in July.

caption:
On Tuesday juniors in the Printmaking department gathered on the first floor of Memorial Hall to share their series of smart work at a final critique. After taking a deep breath, Sophia Oldsman 15 PR tacked up a series of kooky prints portraying two little girls with oversized hands and buggy eyeballs.

In each edition, the cartoonish caricatures are wearing a slightly different costume associated with playful activities such as skating or snowball making. The artist used a vintage black and white photo of her older sisters to anchor the quirky collection. 

Brian Chippendale 97 PR*, a former Printmaking major who is now a well-known comic book artist and noise musician, served as a guest critic for the class taught by Professor Cornelia McSheehy.

“These are super funny. I love it when people embrace the basic repetition of Printmaking,” noted Chippendale while looking over Oldsman’s series. “It would be great to have the room completely plastered with sister activity. Your work feels like it contains a buried joke.”

Oldsman explained that much of her work is inspired by family dynamics. She plans to continue exploring these themes oversees while participating in the European Honors Program in Rome next semester. “I like to use my memories from childhood to guide my work,” she notes. “It’s available subject matter.”

caption:
In response to an assignment from Professor Gareth Jones that asked students in his Foundation Studies Spatial Dynamics class to imagine the phenomena of time and space, Anne Keating 17 FS constructed a layered sheath that is both beautiful and grotesque. Appearing to be riveted with healing bullet holes, the dress (pictured above) is a visual metaphor for the emotional scars everyone carries.

She explained the concept behind the powerful garment at the class’s final crit held on Tuesday. “What if we were all wearing our [psychological] wounds for everyone to see?” Keating asked.“How would that change the way we interact with each other?”

Students attending the crit inferred that the stitched sheath also reminded them of geological landscapes. “There are so many ways to interpret this [piece],” explained Jones. “You can find layers of history here.”

caption:
Just in time for the holidays – and for RISD’s popular Alumni Holiday Art Sale at the RI Convention Center this Saturday – Rhode Island has eliminated its 7% sales tax on artwork. The new law takes effect today (December 1) as RI launches the first statewide arts district in the country.

It’s great news for buyers and most creative vendors, who won’t have to deal with collecting and forwarding the tax on their work. The law stipulates that exempt art must be limited-edition original work “not intended for multiple or mass production.” That includes work like the good giving finds above, along with fine art photography and a handful of other items in the realms of writing and performance.

So, whether it’s at RISD’s own holiday sale this Saturday (which runs from 10 am–5 pm) or through the many other venues and special sales that spring up this month, buy local and buy art. Enhance the value of your giving by simultaneously upporting the gifted makers among us!

caption: Assistant Professor Eduardo Duarte of our Interior Architecture department has the following news to share about the studio that he’s teaching this fall: Layered Worlds. “6 Interior architecture RISD students have just completed their design studio residency in the Pombal Palace in Lisbon. This week-long project is part of their semester research on incorporating the conservational constrains of a XVIII palace (in a considerable status of decay) with the social dynamics of Carpe Diem Arte e Pesquisa - a Lisbon based contemporary art organization that resides in the building. Projects engage multiple spaces in the Palace from the gardens, to the attic, kitchens or stairways. You may see here a glimpse about the projects under development. http://vimeo.com/80061830” and read more about the project in this story on risd.edu. Thanks, Eduardo! -JM

caption:
I was visiting the Met a couple of nights ago as folks were leaving for Thanksgiving to see my buddy George Delgado. George reminded me of how I did a shift with him many moons ago there. I found the pic above when was a bit younger, and I recall that it was a combination of serving up hot food and informal life/majors advising. That evening I realized that’s exactly what George is always quietly doing from his shift there at the Met. Serving up warmth and camaraderie that is free of charge, and with the kind of rich, human spirit that always feels like a once-in-a-lifetime gift. That evening long ago was a humbling and transformative experience for me – so catching George on the night shift as much as possible … has always been my goal on a free evening. Because I learned there that evening what I’ve carried with me from day one – that our students bring phenomenal vision that’s supercharged by our faculty members, and that our hard-working staff members like George and the Met crew, and many others, support those visions with everything they’ve got.

Around the clock, our Public Safety officers are making all points connect across campus by working in concert with our Student Affairs professionals who empower and enable the always-brimming enthusiasm our students bring to our campus community. It is often their voices – the ones who are there 24/7 for our special community – that remind me of what leadership is really all about, often literally. And I feel especially fortunate that we have Chief Operating Officer Jean Eddy giving the personal care and attention to every aspect of a RISD student’s life on campus and beyond.

So on this Thanksgiving Day of 2013, I send my heartfelt thanks on behalf of our institution to the hundreds of staff members, and to their families, who make RISD one of the #1 places to work in this region – who make RISD the #1 design school in the world. Every faculty member here at RISD is *SO* quick to tell me how much RISD’s success is possible because of all your hard work and dedication. So thank YOU, and happy T-day to our RISD! -JM

caption:
RISD/NY held their First Annual Pie Challenge last night, with judges Nate and Kirk Mueller 10 D+M and chef Annie Wayte! The charge was to bring your interpretation of a pie, with prizes awarded for Best Interpretation of a Pie, Most Attractive Pie, and Most Unusual Pie. Entries ranged from traditional to a sculptural “Bacon Pie” to “The Recently Unemployed Pie” and everything in between. Thanks to NY leaders Polly Carpenter 77 PT and Mira Evnine BArch 06 for cooking up this event!

Photos: Matthew Watson 09 FAV

caption:
On Thursday night, visitors to RISD Exposé played wacky carnival games while perusing the zany artworks now on view at Funhaus, an amusing exhibition curated by Claire Goetschel 13 JM that features quirky kitchen accessories, handcrafted furniture and knitted hair accessories. Daisy Hook 14 IA and Lauren Allegrezza 14 PT serve as directors of the student-run space.

In the center of the gallery, visitors grouped around a soft, hanging installation that takes the shape of a long snake. “It reminds me of a pregnancy pillow,” noted Amanda Swain 14 IA. “When I look at it, I imagine two women cuddled up next to it.” 

Others took time to inspect Egg Sweater, a cozy garment knitted by Abby Gallagher 15 TX and Rebel Rocker, a beautifully crafted chair made by Robyn Luk 14 FD. An electrified neon sign wired by Alice Taranto 15 GD was also a hit.

Click on the photos pictured above to get a glimpse of all the Funhaus now on view at RISD Expose through Dec. 1!

Sameer Farooq MFA 14 GD (far right) poses with some of his fellow RISD artists.

caption:
When visiting her family in the South last Christmas eve, Elise Kirk MFA 15 PH managed to create photographic magic. Surrounded by crawfish shells and crumpled up wrapping paper, the graduate student captured a candid moment when her brother told her grandmother a hilarious joke. “My family is a cast of characters,” she explained. “I just waited for right time. Luckily, I got the shot.”

The striking photograph was just one of many brilliant artworks on display during the Scratch n’ Sniff Graduate Open Studios held on Friday, November 15. Throughout the night, members of the public wandered through artist spaces filled with cardboard sculptures, striking portraiture and innovative digital media devices.

Some studios appeared to have weathered the gusts of an angry cyclone. Julie Gautier-Downes MFA 15 PH scattered vintage family portraits, splintered plywood and torn cotton shirts across the floors of her space. The artist wanted to reproduce the interior living area of a doublewide trailer she temporarily slept in while traveling across the Mojave Desert.

“That particular nomadic experience is seared into my memory,” explained Gautier-Downes. “Instead of trying to capture the look of the space in a two-dimensional photograph, I thought it would be more powerful to create a set design.”

Elsewhere in the studio, Goldie Poblador MFA 15 GL displayed glass figurines that look like delicate works of art celebrating the female form. The artist places the cast glass figurines on dessert plates filled with berries. “These [pieces] were created in response to the idea that women are only considered valuable [by society] when their bodies are ripe,” Poblador notes.

On the sixth floor of RISD’s bustling Hot Shop, peckish visitors snacked on gluten-free pizza Jordan Taylor MFA 14 CR fired in one of the kilns. “I remember baking bread in a huge hearth as a child,” Taylor says. “So making pizza in the shop’s ovens feels like old hat.”

Click on the photos above to get a snapshot of RISD’s graduate studios!

Visitors in Fletcher Building check out an impressive installation by Jesse Kaminsky MFA 14 SC.
Goldie Poblador MFA 15 GL decorates her studio with small trinkets, personal writing and images taken in Manila, Philippines.
Otis Gray 14 SC works on his latest iterations of human-shaped sculptures made out of cardboard.
Rob McKirdie MFA 14 SC (far right) shows off his conceptual work constructed out of objects he finds on the street.

caption:
Thanks to a lot of hard work by RISD Illustration faculty member Joe McKendry 94 IL, his wife Susan and the dozens of children’s book illustrators who participated, last month’s We Art Boston fundraiser was a huge success. In response to the Boston Marathon bombing, the McKendries set out to help the community come together through art and raise funds to benefit the Emergency and Trauma Fund at Boston Children’s Hospital. Through the sale of donated artwork and books, they had hoped to raise $30K but ended up surging past that goal to collect a total of $42,926!  

Most importantly, We Art Boston “was a really special gathering of generous artists and volunteers determined to come together to help strengthen our community by sharing time and talent,” McKendry says. “Everyone seemed to have a great time [at the Sunday family event on October 20] and the Children’s Hospital was very grateful for our support.”

caption:
At Thursday’s opening reception for Under the Influence, a Digital + Media exhibition now at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery, Rebecca Zub 08 IL didn’t expect a prank from one of the exhibition pieces. As she bent down to inspect a seemingly simple wooden chair, it unexpectedly sprayed her with a spritz of water. Jason Rabie MFA 14 DM created the cheeky piece by rigging motion sensors to the seat.

It’s just one of the artworks on display in the many-sided show curated by Janet Shih MFA 14 DM and Chihao Yo MFA 14 DM. Throughout the night, students also couldn’t help but play with another humorous piece, The Selfie Machine, by Dillon Froelich 15 ID, Dan Cho 15 ID, Hala Khoursheed 15 ID and Stef Liu 15 ID (second image from the top). It encourages viewers to snap pictures of themselves with their smartphones.

In a nearby vestibule, a small crowd gathered around Soldier (top image), an imposing metal sculpture Otis Gray 15 SC created in response to the Boston Marathon bombing. On close inspection, the hollow figure appears to be wearing a backwards hat and has an American Eagle logo painted on its shoulder.

“[The piece] is supposed to represent the suspects that were behind the bombing, who looked like normal, typical guys,” notes Gray. “Terrorists could literally be anyone. And that’s what’s scary about these random acts of violence.”

Catch Under the Influence through December 11 at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery (2nd floor/Chace Center).

On close inspection, the hollow figure appears to be wearing a backwards hat and has an American Eagle logo painted on its shoulder.

“[The piece] is supposed to represent the suspects that were behind the bombing, who looked like normal, typical guys,” notes Gray. “Terrorists could literally be anyone. And that’s what’s scary about these random acts of violence.”

Catch Under the Influence through December 11 at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery (2nd floor/Chace Center).

trail.content:
At Thursday’s opening reception for Under the Influence, a Digital + Media exhibition now at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery, Rebecca Zub 08 IL didn’t expect a prank from one of the exhibition pieces. As she bent down to inspect a seemingly simple wooden chair, it unexpectedly sprayed her with a spritz of water. Jason Rabie MFA 14 DM created the cheeky piece by rigging motion sensors to the seat.

It’s just one of the artworks on display in the many-sided show curated by Janet Shih MFA 14 DM and Chihao Yo MFA 14 DM. Throughout the night, students also couldn’t help but play with another humorous piece, The Selfie Machine, by Dillon Froelich 15 ID, Dan Cho 15 ID, Hala Khoursheed 15 ID and Stef Liu 15 ID (second image from the top). It encourages viewers to snap pictures of themselves with their smartphones.

In a nearby vestibule, a small crowd gathered around Soldier (top image), an imposing metal sculpture Otis Gray 15 SC created in response to the Boston Marathon bombing. On close inspection, the hollow figure appears to be wearing a backwards hat and has an American Eagle logo painted on its shoulder.

“[The piece] is supposed to represent the suspects that were behind the bombing, who looked like normal, typical guys,” notes Gray. “Terrorists could literally be anyone. And that’s what’s scary about these random acts of violence.”

Catch Under the Influence through December 11 at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery (2nd floor/Chace Center).

caption:
Prior to the recent board of trustees meeting, a few trustees hosted small community dinners for faculty, students, and staff. Trustee Glass hosted one for students, and is pictured above.

Presidents Glenn (undergrads) and Wagner (grads) addressed the board of trustees (in the photos above), with Presidents Yan (alumni) and Pietropaoli (staff council) together with Professor Anne Tate (faculty meeting steering committee).

While going between committee meetings I snapped Dean Sharma’s silhouette as we were leaving the Chace Center (above). I feel fortunate to get to work with so many amazing people, like Pradeep, here at RISD. -JM

caption: A few days ago RISD welcomed over a thousand alumni and parents back to campus for RISD by Design weekend. Events included an inspiring lecture by Jarrett Krosoczka 99 IL, the ever-popular Alumni and Student Art Sale, a panel on artrepreneurship with President Maeda, alumni-driven art from Breanne Trammell MFA 08 PR and Jane Kim 03 PR and Open Studios from 16 departments across campus! We hope you made it back and had a boatload of fun, but if not (or if you’re already reminiscing), check out our photo gallery and more posts from the weekend.

caption: Virgina MacDonald 43 AE (center) celebrated her 70th reunion at last weekend’s RISD by Design event, catching up with Richard Parker 47 GD, the second oldest alum in attendance. The two former classmates chattedat the Half Century luncheon and recalled shared experiences before Uncle Sam called Richard away to serve in WWII. RISD Archives supplied the Class of 1943 yearbook for the event, provoking many fond memories and more than a few laughs. Viriginia’s daughter Mary MacDonald 76 IA (far left) also participated, having driven her mother in from the Cape.

caption: I was with President Neil Steinberg of the RI Foundation yesterday. Neil heads a local foundation that grants generous “genius” awards like the MacArthur prizes – one of our graduates, Adrienne Gagnon, just received one of these prestigious fellowships. The Rhode Island Foundation has just launched a fantastic new video series that features our local economic innovators who are making a big difference. Thank you to Neil and the Rhode Island Foundation for all of your leadership in keeping Rhode Island great! -JM

tags: cream of the crop with a
caption:
On Saturday night, a pack of models wearing fringed sashes, scored tights and neon face markings gathered on an illuminated street corner outside 204 Westminster, the permanent storefront that’s home to RISD Exposé and 2nd Life. The wild creations were part of a primal collection designed by Carmel Dunlap 14 TX.

“I’m really interested in the idea of self-camouflage. The way people dress is subconsciously dictated by their environments,” explains Dunlap. “To play with this concept, I like to make apparel that’s a mix of urban streetwear and tribal clothing.”

The designs were included in Cream of the Crop, The Cherry on Top, the first exhibition hosted by RISD Exposé, the school’s edgy student-curated art space.

Visitors to the show were also impressed with an interactive computer game and a blue-hued pigment print inspired by Anchorage, Alaska. Another popular piece was a loaf of bread constructed out of wood and polyurethane bumpers.

Click here to learn more about RISD Exposé!

caption:
William Wells 11 ID has got his business model in the bag. Visitors who attended Saturday’s Alumni and Student Art Sale snatched up stacks of his eco-friendly wallets made from a blend of recycled low-density polyethylene and textile scraps.

The industrial designer operates his company, The Providence Plastic Project, with the help of Steven W. Greco 11 ID and Ryan Venghaus. The entrepreneurs experiment with reused materials in a studio located in Providence’s Butcher Block Mill. “We’re dedicated to making consumer products out of dry cleaner bags, newspaper sleeves, and discarded fabric,” notes Wells.

Onlookers were also pleased to find couture millinery crafted by Anne DePasquale 93 TX and handknit baby sweaters by Meredith Gladstone 64 AP. Other shoppers were drawn to a table that showcased colorful paintings made by David Aipperspach MFA PT 14.

The sale was just one piece of RISD by Design, the annual alumni reunion and parents weekend. Earlier in the morning, President John Maeda led a lively discussion in the Chace Center Auditorium that touched upon the ways creativity and artistic experimentation stimulates innovation and economic advancement. RISD faculty, staff and alumni also explained some of the excellent campus programs that help students kickstart their own start-ups.

Over in the metal studio, RISD alumni and Sculpture students fired up the drill press to build a towering bird-like sculpture out of aluminum and discarded wire. When it was complete, the metalsmiths stepped back to observe their work. “It’s so surreal to be here,” noted Noah Breuer 04 PR. “It’s almost like stepping into a familiar dream.”

Later that night, sports fans filed into the bleachers in Brown’s Meehan Ice Rink to support The Nads, RISD’s scrappy co-ed ice hockey team. Wearing scarves and zippered jackets, the crowd cheered on the current team who faced off against former players. “I’m so torn. Who do I root for?” exclaimed Candace Reeve BArch 10 with a huge grin. “But no matter who wins, it’s great to be back at RISD.”

To read more about the wonderful work seen at the art sale, click on the photos above!

caption:
photos by Karen Pietropaoli

Spirits soared and the weather cooperated for the third annual Pumpkinpalooza in Market Square last Friday, October 11. Organized by RISD’s Staff Council, the festive event is held at the beginning of RISD by Design weekend to help raise funds for the annual Staff Council Student Award, which provides two seniors with $500 gift cards good at the risd:store and the RISD Store 3D.

At this year’s gathering, students, staff and a smattering of parents bought pumpkins and treats, guessed at the number of candy corns in a jar and enjoyed ambient mood music by OIT’s Rick Lescault and blues- and reggae-infused grooves by Imade Agus Winangun in Facilities. Master pumpkin carver George Nickolopoulos was also on hand working his magic to create an outlandish steam punk jack-o-lantern.

Josette and Dominic Dannessa, who were here from Chicago visiting their daughter Kate, stopped to enjoy the music and a cup of coffee. “Kate fell in love with RISD’s campus and the downtown Providence vibe,” said her mom. “And it’s so nice for us to be able to walk to campus from our hotel room at the Biltmore.”

At this year’s gathering, students, staff and a smattering of parents bought pumpkins and treats, guessed at the number of candy corns in a jar and enjoyed ambient mood music by OIT’s Rick Lescault and blues- and reggae-infused grooves by Imade Agus Winangun in Facilities. Master pumpkin carver George Nickolopoulos was also on hand working his magic to create an outlandish steam punk jack-o-lantern.

Josette and Dominic Dannessa, who were here from Chicago visiting their daughter Kate, stopped to enjoy the music and a cup of coffee. “Kate fell in love with RISD’s campus and the downtown Providence vibe,” said her mom. “And it’s so nice for us to be able to walk to campus from our hotel room at the Biltmore.”

caption:
On Thursday Annie Irwin 15 TX inspected a most curious ceramic installation in Woods-Gerry Gallery. The textiles major hunched over to check out a cluster of white ceramic pieces strung up by fishing wire.

“It looks like large teeth are floating in mid-air,” she noted. “Could it be floss that’s holding them up?”

The whimsical piece is included in the Ceramics Departmental Exhibition. The show also includes tube-like earthenware, glazed pottery and hilariously morbid figurines.

See the photos above to learn more about beautiful work included in the exhibition, which runs through October 20 in Woods-Gerry Gallery!

caption:
On Friday night students mingled – and snacked on rainbow-colored cupcakes - during a happening party that celebrated RISD Exposé, a student-curated art space. As soft hip hop beats reverberated off the walls, the dapper creatives discussed The Cream of the Crop, The Cherry on Top, an upcoming show that will feature edgy, slightly off-kilter work.

The artists and designers also checked out 2nd Life, RISD’s student-run materials resource center that collects and distributes art supplies. Visitors routinely pilfer expensive materials – including high-end leather, centuries-old wood and cans of paint – from the storefront. Both organizations are housed in 204 Westminster, a charming building located in downtown Providence.

Winston Cuevas 15 ID attended the mixer to let his peers know about E'Ship, a campus club that helps students find resources – financial and social – to support their own ambitious business ventures. Last spring, organizers forged a working relationship with entrepreneurs who attend Brown University.

“This fall we’re hosting networking events with venture capitalists and other professionals,” notes Cuevas. “It’s going to be exciting year.” 

Be sure to check out The Cream of the Crop, The Cherry on Top, which is slated to open Saturday, October 12 at 7 pm!

caption:
“What could be underneath the bricks?“ whispered Katrina Ellis while inspecting a curious installation made of red brick in RISD’s Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery. “I feel as if the wall is moving with life.”

As it turns out, the intriguing installation by Jordan Taylor MFA 14 CR plays with the relationship between two geological phenomena: syncline and angle of repose. This is just one of many intricate artworks unveiled at last Thursday’s opening reception of Complexity, an evocative exhibition curated by Steve Pestana MFA 14 DM. The show that also features a few pieces by faculty and staff showcases intricate artwork made from combinations of simple elements.

In a nearby corner of the gallery, visitors couldn’t help but chuckle as they played with a computer program designed by Marissa Goldman 15 FAV. The piece is a digital self-portrait that explores the frustrating demands of technology as well as the universe. As viewers click on the interface, a pixelated version of Goldman angrily asks them to stop.

“You’re pushing my buttons!” shouts the tiny artist from the screen. “Why won’t you stop? You’re literally not listening to me!”

Don’t miss out on all the interactive fun! Complexity is on view through Sunday, October 27 at the Gelman Student Exhibitions Gallery located on the 2nd floor of RISD’s Chace Center.

caption:
Professor Lindsay French in our History, Philosophy and the Social Sciences department dropped by a pre-release DVD of Krom Akphiwat Phum: Rural Development in Battambang Province — her sabbatical collaboration with Professor Peter O’Neill in our FAV department. RISD’s strong internationalism is represented by the diversity of our faculty’s interests—I think I have encountered almost every country in some shape or form here at RISD. Congratulations and thanks for introducing me to  Cambodia, Lindsay and Peter! -JM

caption:
Approximately 75 members of the RISD community who attended Serving Up Summer, a lovely Monday luncheon organized by the RISD Staff Council, enjoyed a mouthwatering assortment of gourmet foods: infused spinach tortellini, fresh green salads with oven-roasted tomatoes and smoked chicken gouda over polenta cake.

But in addition to feeling pleasantly full, attendees left with a case of the warm fuzzies as funds raised at the special event benefit the Rhode Island Community Food Bank. The nonprofit agency is a wonderful philanthropic organization that works to reduce hunger throughout the region. Students enrolled in The Community Kitchen, a 14-week culinary training program for low-income and unemployed adults, helped to prepare the tasty dishes.

“This is a perfect example of how RISD is a positive influence on the Providence community and beyond,” noted RISD President John Maeda, who attended the event. 

The foodies also got a crash course in how to make their latest meals at home. Chef Antonio DaCosta Jr., one of the culinary masters at Parkside Rotiserrie & Bar, instructed audience members on how to make the perfect blueberry lemon shortcake. Chef Thomas Hunold, a banquet manager at Renaissance Hotel in Providence, explained the art of preparing appetizers.

Lynne McCormack 87 FAV, director of Art, Culture and Tourism for the City of Providence, also stopped by the luncheon at RISD’s Portfolio Café to see the good work in action. “These programs really do change lives for the better,” she confirmed.

Curious to see the cooking demonstrations? Check out this recording of Serving Up Summer!

photos.caption: Chef Antonio DaCosta Jr. shows luncheon goers how to make the perfect blueberry lemon shortcake.
Cassie Goryl, training and communications coordinator for RISD's Human Resources Department, shows off her plate of chicken gouda.
The key to making a tasty blueberry lemon shortcake dessert is to keep the ingredients warm at all times.

caption:
On a long white table Blake Hiltunen MFA 14 SC spread out a curious sampling of his latest work: craggy cement busts, cast iron growths and gold-plated insects. Visitors to the sculptor’s studio especially tended to linger over a small plaster hand detailed with crystalized monoammonium phosphate.

“My work is rooted in the relationship between preservation and the earth’s evolution,” notes Hiltunen. “It tends to evoke a really strong response from some people.”

The corporal sculptures were shown as part of Art Twerk, a special event held in RISD’s graduate studios last Thursday as part of Gallery Night Providence, a city-wide celebration that gives art lovers access to popular venues throughout the city. Hao Ni MFA 14 SC and Roque Montez MFA 14 PR organized the juried exhibition of RISD work, which featured experimental sculpture, printmaking, painting and digital media. 

Elsewhere in the hardwood studios, visitors heard a soft clacking sound as Maggie Casey MFA 14 SC and Ben Young (pictured in the photo second from the top) took turns walking through their installation made from beaded bamboo strands. The multi-layered piece doubles as a room divider and a large-scale optical illusion. “It’s interesting to see whether people choose to step through it or not,” notes Casey. “Maybe it could be used as a tool for a social science experiment.”

Down the hall, a small crowd also converged on a collection of looming Tyvek installations made by Jesse Kaminsky MFA 14 SC (pictured in the bottom photo). The graduate student specializes in making impressive inflatables that take the shape of gangly sea creatures. 

To read more about the intriguing work featured in Art Twerk, click on the photos above!

caption:
photos by Matthew Clowney

As part of the latest summer studio organized by Project Open Door (POD), 11 ambitious Rhode Island teenagers spent a week in the basement of ProvWash building out their portfolios before applying to colleges. Sculptural Lighting, taught by  Industrial Design and Foundation Studies faculty member Michael Lamar MFA 84 CR, provided students with their first in-depth experience designing and building in 3D. Check out this story on risd.edu for more.

caption: We held our annual staff picnic today at Tillinghast Farms. Hundreds of RISD staff members and their families turned out for this special yearly tradition in our community. The weather was perfect, the food was amazing, and the family activities were great fun. Thank you to the Staff Picnic Committee and our Human Resources area for making another great RISD picnic happen! -JM

caption:
Professor Markus Berger in our Interior Architecture department sent me a pic of an installation that was up a few weeks back by the 30+ MDES students as led by Professors Eduardo Duarte, Wolfgang Rudorf and Skender Luarasi as described below: 

240 lbs of RISD 2nd life in suspension in CIT 

The installation is part of an on-going collaboration between Interior Architecture MDes Summer Program and RISD 2nd Life. The project is structured by a web of suspended yellow twine laced along the hinges of 4 doors in CIT room #103. Ten groups of 3 MDes Grad students were invited to randomly select 8 lbs of  salvaged materials from the inventory of RISD 2nd Life. Each group determined associative principles to combine and display the selected materials 240 lbs across the yellow twine web in CIT room #103. Along a period of 3 days, each group had 4 instances of 30 minutes to dispose 24 lbs of material. Every group were restricted to anchor every material lb to the yellow twine web without reaching the wooden floor. In 3 days the room became an unpredictable, flexible, adaptable, random,complex, illogical, and collectively made network hoping to bring awareness to the multiplicity of adaptive reuse.

There’s nothing like 240 lbs of “floating stuff” … Thanks, Marcus and team! -JM

caption: Just heard from Professor John Caserta in our Graphic Design department and his mates at their popular workshare — if you visit our highly acclaimed Locally Made show now up at our museum, you’ll see their locally made work along with 300 other artists and designers that have made the good choice of setting up shop here in Rhode Island. -JM

caption:
A new book by Professor Clara Lieu in Foundation Studies is now out on the art of teaching art. You can read a 6-page excerpt right here. Congratulations, Clara!

And next month a new book is forthcoming by our Provost Rosanne Somerson and Executive Director of Strategic Planning and Academic Initiatives Mara Hermano entitled, “The Art of Critical Making.” More on that shortly. -JM

caption:
While attending Design the Night, an upbeat block party hosted by the RISD Museum on Thursday night, Carolyn Marsden received some interesting news. In the public workshop The Pangolin Within: Power Animals, Extinction and Symbiosis, the art director of Rhode Island Monthly was informed her spirit guide is what sailors call “the salty dog of the sea.”

“I was told my inner spirit animal is the seal,” explained Marsden. “Seals are quite fierce – so I’m OK with this information. I was also advised to swim at my own pace.”

The workshop was lead by Beth Nixon, a performance artist who sometimes goes by her alter ego Ruth Nibbons, MFA. It was just one of the festive programs held at the RISD Museum to celebrate the opening of Locally Made, a multi-media extravaganza featuring the work of over 300 Rhode Island artists.

Toward the end of the night, the fun spilled out from the museum onto the cobblestone streets outside. Bluegrass band Joe Fletcher & the Wrong Reasons played an uptempo show as small children danced with frozen lemonades in hand.

“This is such a fun summer event,” noted Jen McCaffery, associate editor of Rhode Island Monthly. “Everyone’s tapping their feet. What’s better than art and music?”

To learn more about Locally Made, check out this story on risd.edu!

caption:
This summer Charlotte Potter MFA 10 GL is getting weird. The glass artist is organizing a sprawling visual arts arena to add some psychedelic flair to Grand Point North, a booming music festival held in the green hills of Vermont in September. As the lead singer of Grace Potter and the Nocturnals, Potter’s sister is headlining the two-day event with other world-famous acts including Gov’t Mule, Charles Bradley and Trombone Shorty.

Dubbed Grand Point Weird, the arts arena will include a whimsical tent constructed by Brett Day Windham MFA 10 SC where viewers can view her video art. Under another larger canopy, visitors can see additional media work made by local artists and creatives in the RISD community. Fantastically freakish installations will also dot the grounds surrounding the pop-up galleries.

“Visitors to Grand Point Weird can expect to see poignant pieces that have a touch of carnival,” notes Potter. “One of my goals is to make art accessible to the public. This music festival is the perfect venue to make that happen.”

Potter plans to exhibit Bottled Emotion, a performance art piece where she asks willing participants to exhale their feelings into a pipe that inflates molten glass into a bubble. After the glass cools down, each participant walks away with his or her own piece of blown glassware. “There’s a lot of really raw, beautiful work that comes from this piece,” she notes.

To submit work to be included in Grand Point Weird, email an electronic application to Charlotte Potter at cpotter@g.risd.edu. The deadline for submissions is August 15. And selected artists will be awarded tickets to the concert!

caption:
Wearable sculpture (top to bottom left to right) by Yong Joo Kim, Robin Quigley, Yoshie Enda, Lauren Tickle, Kate Furman and Mariah Tuttle

Jewelry + Metalsmithing Department Head  Robin Quigley MFA 76 SC and Associate Professor Tracy Steepy have joined forces this summer with jewelry designers from Monash Art Design and Architecture (MADA) in Australia to mount an exciting new show that opened yesterday.

Co-curated by Quigley and award-winning MADA professor Marian Hosking, Seams|Seems brings together work by 20 artists from RISD and MADA (with a focus on alumni from the graduate programs) and explores the notion of how they are moving their work beyond wearable forms and into the realm of sculpture. “This is an opportunity to create a dialogue between jewelers and small object makers from the US and Australia to see where we diverge and where we converge,” Hosking notes.

A highlight of the exhibition is a one-day symposium on July 19 featuring keynote speaker Robert Bell, senior curator of Decorative Arts and Design at the National Gallery of Australia, Canberra. Quigley, Steepy and several celebrated MADA jewelry designers are also presenting talks.

The exhibition continues through August 20 at MADA’s Caulfield campus outside of Melbourne. RISD ise represented with work from Quigley and Steepy as well as seven alumni: Yoshi Enda MFA 10 JM, Kate Furman MFA 12 JM, Yong Joo Kim MFA 09 JM, Hye Yeon Park 12 JM, Lauren Tickle MFA 09 JM, Mariah Tuttle MFA 11 JM and Mallory Weston MFA 13 JM.

caption:
RISD alumni Grace Glass 11 IL and Lucas Lefler BArch 12 began collaborating before even graduating, notably on a blog inspired by the 2011 book Between Artists, which lets the reader in on a visual conversation between artist compadres Barbara Bloom and John Baldessari. “We decided to develop our own conversation about visual ideas in the form of a blog,” says Glass. That conversation led to inspiring collaborations and projects and ultimately to their own design firm: gg-ll.

Since its inception in 2012, the New York-based gg-ll has produced advertising and editorial work with a singular style that features overexposed photography, geometric shapes and pastels. “Our strength,” says Glass, “lies in our multidisciplinary approach.” Clients include Levi’s Made and Crafted, BULLETT magazine, menswear designer Duckie Brown and fellow RISD grad and fashion designer Sarah Richards 11 AP.

And the design world is beginning to take note. London-based online publication It’s Nice That describes gg-ll’s work as “the kind of luxurious fashion editorial and photographic campaigns that we’re always happy to lust over” and predicts “a stratospheric rise to the big time.” Fasten your seat belts!

caption:
photography by Cathy Carver, courtesy of CUE Art Foundation

Last week The Brooklyn Rail ran a great review of a recent solo show of paintings by Professor Dennis Congdon 75 PT.

“Congdon’s gentle touch, his almost dusty colors, and his precise but unintimidating stenciled lines smooth over the pitfalls and abysses of history, lending an explanatory continuity that only the artist or the historian can invent," wrote critic William Corwin.

Congdon’s solo show ran at CUE Gallery in Chelsea from June 1 through July 6. Read more about it in our story Big Ideas on RISD’s main website.

caption:
A compelling blend of photography and interactive motion installations can be seen in the Rhode Island School of Design 2013 MFA Graduate Show, a group exhibition on view at the NYC gallery space ClampArt. It features the work of six fabulously talented graduate students who just graduated from the Photography department. 

The exhibition is garnering some much-deserved attention from the media. “Though each photographer’s series is very different, a sense of depth overwhelms every photo and pulls the collection together,” Lauren Espeseth notes on Cool Hunting. “And at the same time, the labyrinth-like layout of the space feeds [viewers’] excitement to turn each corner.”

The charmingly offbeat show is on view until Saturday, July 20, in the intimate Chelsea gallery. Click on the photos pictured above to learn more about the photographers’ captivating artwork!

A compelling blend of photography and interactive motion installations can be seen in the Rhode Island School of Design 2013 MFA Graduate Show, a group exhibition on view at the NYC gallery space ClampArt. It features the work of six fabulously talented graduate students who just graduated from the Photography department. 

The exhibition is garnering some much-deserved attention from the media. “Though each photographer’s series is very different, a sense of depth overwhelms every photo and pulls the collection together,” Lauren Espeseth notes on Cool Hunting. “And at the same time, the labyrinth-like layout of the space feeds [viewers’] excitement to turn each corner.”

The charmingly offbeat show is on view until Saturday, July 20, in the intimate Chelsea gallery. Click on the photos pictured above to learn more about the photographers’ captivating artwork!

caption:
Last Friday educators from across the US who instruct students in grades K-12 were immersed in a most engaging activity. Recent RISD graduate Sarah Pease 13 FD led a workshop in the Materials Resource Center that asked the teachers to package a single potato chip for mailing. The challenge was to make sure the delicate edible would arrive at its final destination in one piece.

“The exercise focused on the practical applications of design thinking,” explained Pease. “The educators were all very resourceful. They came up with some really inventive solutions.”

The fun activity was part of the RISD STEAM Colloquium, an all-day event that allowed the educators to tour the RISD campus and learn more about STEAM, a movement championed by RISD that encourages the integration of arts and design into STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, Math).

The educators also visited the wondrous Edna Lawrence Nature Lab to listen to an impassioned talk by Meghan Reilly Michaud 01 GD, president of the Alumni Council. The high school teacher led a brainstorming session on ways to incorporate inspiring STEAM principles into lesson plans. The educators then drew gelatinous sea creatures using electron microscopes.

Later in the day, the educators visited the Industrial Design Building to hear Assistant Professor Cas Holman explain the educational value of play. For the past nine years, she has designed playground equipment that sparks children’s imaginations while simultaneously teaching basic engineering and design skills.

“Never before has there been this much of a need to incorporate design thinking into school curriculum,” noted Sarah Cappelli, an art educator who teaches in the Providence school system. “STEAM promotes critical thinking skills that are necessary for our students to develop in order to compete professionally in the 21st century.” 

To learn how you can get involved in the STEM to STEAM movement, see this website!

caption:
On Saturday, 197 graduate and 462 undergraduate students – some decked out graduation garb decorated with papier-mâché creatures, fake flowers and other unorthodox objects – attended RISD’s 2013 Commencement ceremony to accept their hard-earned degrees. As students danced their way into the Rhode Island Convention Center, an exuberant marching band trumpeted up-tempo ragtime tunes.

Speaking on behalf of graduate students, Raine Vasquez MFA 13 PR spoke eloquently about love, art and creativity, noting that they all involve an element of risk and danger. Jessie Chen 13 FAV also gave an impassioned talk encouraging fellow graduates to transcend boundaries in order to create the kind of world they envision.

In addition to receiving an honorary degree for her amazing work as an artist and illustrator, Maira Kalman delivered a humorous and heartfelt Commencement address.

“Go forth with kindness, meanness, courage, fear, compassion. Go forth with knowing and having no idea – and knowing that having no idea is completely acceptable and real. Commence with confusion,” noted Kalman. “Commence with a sense of humor. Walk, breathe, retreat. Commence with an idea… It’ll be amazing to see what you do.”

Check out this story on risd.edu to read more about those honored at RISD’s 2013 Commencement ceremony and watch videos of the speakers’ speeches!

photos.caption: After accepting her honorary degree for her amazing work as an artist and illustrator, Maira Kalman delivered a humorous and heartfelt Commencement address.
Eager to receive their diplomas, students danced into the Rhode Island Convention Center.
Students accepted their diplomas decked out in tiaras, paper costumes and glittery mortarboards.
In true RISD fashion, students decorated their graduation attire with flowers, sequins and other eye-catching objects.
At the start of the ceremony, The Extraordinary Rendition Band trumpeted up-tempo ragtime tunes.
Raine Vasquez MFA 13 PR compared and contrasted art to the symptoms associated with romantic love.
Representing the undergraduate class, Jessie Chen 13 FAV gave an impassioned talk that encouraged her peers to break through boundaries.
Environmental activist and distinguished artist Bill McKibben was given an honorary degree.
Last Saturday, 197 graduate and 462 undergraduate students became the newest class of artists and designers to graduate from RISD.

caption:
As students leisurely inspect the engaging body of work on view at the Graduate Thesis Exhibition, their musings are interrupted by a loud crack resounding throughout the custom-constructed galleries. The sound emanates from Shush, a wooden statement piece rooted in psychology. Its hammer slams down on a lever that pummels a bronze face. 

“It’s a metaphor for the influences that silence us – whether they are subconscious or blatantly obvious to us, ” notes Quintin Rivera Toro MFA 13 SC, the creator of the piece.

After a few good whacks at the opening, the fulcrum snapped. The sculptor stood guard to protect the piece from further damage. “Sorry everyone. It’s out of commission for now,” he said. “But I’ll get it back in working order.”

Students were also drawn to Good Object 2, a large installation by Anna Huemmer MFA 13 SC made of orange traffic cones. “There’s so much to see,” said one student while making his way through the crowd. With almost 200 grad students showcasing work at the show, it’s a definite understatement.

The exhibition continues through June 1 in the Rhode Island Convention Center.

caption:
Professor Andrew Raftery in Printmaking shared with me:

“For the past year and a half I have been working on an exhibition of American Narrative Prints at the National Academy Museum. It has been a great experience, and there are some really beautiful and unusual prints in the show.”

The opening for the summer exhibitions is on Wednesday, May 22. There will be panel at which you can see Andrew in action on Wednesday, June 26 from 6:30 PM, and on Friday, July 26 at 3 PM. Congratulations Andrew! -JM

caption:
Wayne Assing, Director of Student Development and Counseling, sent me a few photos from our dedication ceremony of two trees planted in celebration of RISD parents Dick and Catherine Haining (pictured above next to the plaque that sits between the trees) located in RISD’s new stone sitting garden, located in Thompson yard.

Wayne says of the garden project, “I believe that in the days and years ahead this will become a respite for students to have a quiet and relaxing moment or to have a good conversation with a good friend.”

Thanks to the fine folks in Facilities and in Wayne’s office, and special thanks to Pat Brown in Institutional Engagement! -JM

caption:
Billowy capes, structured jackets, sophisticated evening gowns  – and even avant-garde bodysuits that take the shape of rhombuses – were some of the fantastical fashions modeled at Collection 2013. The annual runway show was held this Saturday at the Rhode Island Convention Center.

The popular show gives the public a taste of the trendsetting looks crafted by students in the Apparel Design department. In the moments leading up to the start of the show, Maybelline make-up artists were busy primping models as the designers made last-minute adjustments to their garments.

Tommy Hilfiger enjoyed the show from a front row seat. The founder of Tommy USA was one of the guest critics who gave students feedback on their work throughout the year.

Click through the photos to read up on the designers who made these fashion-forward works of art!

caption:
The biggest and most anticipated student exhibition of the year opens tomorrow – Thursday, May 16 from 6–8 pm. And while some grad students may not be quite ready, the rest of us can’t wait to see the work they’ve thrown their hearts, minds and incredible skill into making this year.

The Graduate Thesis Exhibition totally transforms the Rhode Island Convention Center’s cavern of a space – Hall A – into an edgy contemporary gallery showcasing the work of almost 200 students from all 16 graduate departments.

So know that the handful of images shown above are just a tease (click on them for credits). You’ll need to go see for yourself – either at the opening and/or any day thereafter from 12–5, through Commencement day, June 1.

caption:
How do the notions of value and currency enter into art and personal adornment? Jewelry designer Lauren Tickle MFA 09 JM plays with this question in her Increasing Value series, using American dollars to create awe-inspiring brooches, cufflinks, and other pieces. “My work takes underlying materialism and makes it explicit,” says Tickle.

Tickle was recently named one of eight winners (out of more than 200 entries) of the Preziosa Young 2013 Design Competition run by Le Arti Orafe — a contemporary jewelry school in Florence, Italy. Her work will be on display in Italy, Germany and Poland this summer as part of the contest’s traveling exhibition. She had the added distinction of being named winner of the Special Award at Inhorgenta Munich 2014.

Closer to home, Tickle has been busy creating Increasing Value earrings and necklaces for sale at the MoMA Design Store in NYC. MoMA chose her as one of 175 designers to participate in its Destination NYC show this summer, which focuses on innovative materials and production methods as well as relevance to contemporary design.

caption:
Cynthia Poon 13 ID pulled back a sheet of fabric, crouched down low and entered a cocoon of warm colors and soft light. The industrial designer had followed her friend into Book of Leaves, a beautiful tent-like structure made by Stephanie Chung 13 PR. The piece was constructed out of plexiglas rods and painted fabric. 

“When you’re inside, the fabric looks illuminated,” Poon noted while running her hand through the interior cloth lining the structure. “You have to become a part of the piece to appreciate it to the fullest.”

The veiled framework was just one of the interactive pieces on view at the Printmaking Senior Exhibition opening reception held at Woods-Gerry on Thursday. The show runs through April 30. 

Others flocked to Dancin’ With Myself, a live performance by Kathleen Villari 13 PR. The printmaker danced on a stage decorated with pink fabric pieces in the shape of limbs. 

Students also couldn’t help but notice Corpuscule, a large mixed media piece by Andrew Kensett 13 PR that hangs from the foyer in Woods-Gerry. 

To read more about the wonderful pieces on view at the Printmaking Senior Exhibition, click on the photos above!

caption: Graduate Student Alliance President Yuki Kawae shared with me their “15 minute studio” visit concept. You could call it the evolution of “pechakucha” in one sense, or else the emergence of a constructive “flash mob” approach to sharing viewpoints here on campus among our graduate students. In any case, it’s a simple, brilliant idea by our graduate student leadership team. You can check for regular Fast / High-Noon events on our new events board here as an example. -JM

caption:
Paige Devries 13 PT routinely works with found objects to make mixed media pieces inspired by the poetry of Maggie Nelson and Anne Pierson Wiese. For example, her unusual piece A Cut, A Section, A Slice of Someone’s Orange II is constructed out of sparkly geological gems and oil on canvas.

“I use whatever I can get my hands on,” explains Devries. “My work encapsulates the good, the bad and the ugly.” 

The piece is just one of many on display in the Painting Senior Exhibition in Woods-Gerry. Boxes of light, playful installations and brightly painted canvasses are also on view. 

Visitors of the gallery can also find large scale sculptural work by Eriko Hattori 13 PT. The senior says her work has a feminine presence that’s rooted in spirituality. “My art is a witness to Buddhist practices and my own heritage,” she notes.

Ted Craig 14 PT visited the exhibition during Thursday’s opening reception. He was happy to see his fellow students’ artwork. “I think the exhibition is really well designed. Everything is just so cohesive,” he notes. “And the work is really thoughtful.”

The exhibition will run through April 9. Click on the photos above to read more about the artists represented in the senior show. Note: one of the pieces cleverly incorporates a pair of potatoes.

photos.caption: Michael Rose 13 PT used oil paint to make a multi-colored piece titled Oranges.
Karis Choi 13 PT made this eye-catching installation out of neon, LED light and Plexiglas.
I Want You So Badly, a piece by Joon Taylor 13 PT, was constructed out of metal, wood, plastic and "various corn syrup treats."
Delivery, a piece Michael Rose PT 13, is made out of aluminum, string and Plexiglas.
This installation by Thomas Laprade 13 PT is made of potato, tent poles and grommets.
Woo Jin Chung 13 PT rigged Expect Resistance, an installation made from fabric, stretcher bars, rope, plaster and wood.
This piece by William Cassidy 13 PT was crafted using watercolors, walnut ink, charcoal, twine and bone.
To Be Polished is a beautiful wooden installation by Alice Glasser 13 PT. It was made out of found wood and coconut oil.
Paige Devries 13 PT made this piece titled A Cut, A Section, A Slice of Someone's Orange II out of oil paint and mixed materials (including rocks).

caption:
In Introduction to Basic Shoemaking – a studio offered by RISD's Apparel Design and Industrial Design departments ­– Critic Marika Verploegh Chasse is teaching students how to make a pair of basic leather pumps, from start to finish.

By the time the class ends, Joseph Escobar 13 ID will make a pair of five-inch wedges using materials he routinely encounters in his industrial design classes: wood and metal. “My design is going to be absolutely wild,” he says.

Curious to read more about RISD students’ inventive shoe designs? See this story on risd.edu!

photos.caption: Sitting on metal stools, a band of students wearing dust-covered aprons circles around the Swiss shoemaker.
John Bai 14 ID hunches over a drafting table as he vigorously scrapes the outer edges of a piece of brown leather.
Students use small knives to cut pieces of leather to fit a shoe design. Then the leather is draped on a wooden shoe model (called a "last").
Shoemaking is an intensive process that requires an enormous amount of patience.

caption:
RISD's Edna Lawrence Nature Lab is a treasure trove of rare curiosities. A playground of scientific exploration, the campus resource allows students to explore the patterns and structures found in nature to create uniquely organic approaches to design. 

On a typical weekday, RISD students can be found on the first floor sketching the anatomy of the human skeletal system using bony models (see photo above). Others snap photos of pretty snakeskin to whip up their next piece of digital fabric.

“So many of these patterns found in nature can be applied to textiles, painting and more,” notes Margaret Parish 15 SC who works at the lab. “There’s endless inspiration to draw upon here.”

And there are plenty of things that make the skin crawl. Snakes, poison dart frogs and hissing cockroaches inhabit plexiglass cages. Egg sacks containing hundreds of praying mantises are captured in terrariums. Spiky puffer fish line ceiling rafters. “You can find some real freaky things,” says Parish with a laugh.

Tucked away in a cabinet is a jarred baby fetus, a morning dove and a hoard of amphibians. Embalmed in formaldehyde, their delicate structures will remain unchanged. “I don’t spend much time poking around here because it smells a bit,” notes Parish.

If the pickled specimens fail to incite a shudder, visitors can move on to the microscopes. Through a lens, the amateur scientists witness tiny creatures eating, moving and procreating (usually unnoticed) in a bead of water. The organisms appear to be slinking around among groups of cells.

“It’s important to remember that there are living things – whole creatures – living in the minute details,” notes Parish. “It sparks the imagination.”

Can’t get enough of the creepy-crawly items found in the Edna Lawrence Nature Lab? See this video produced by Etsy!

photos.caption: Margaret Parish 14 SC holds up a morning dove preserved in formaldehyde.
These ctenophora (also known as comb jellies) live in the bottom floor of the Edna Lawrence Nature Lab.
Rebecca Richards 16 FS works on a clay model of a human skull.
This large swan is considered the prize of the lab's taxidermy collection.
Students can borrow specimens housed in the Edna Lawrence Nature Lab.
Margaret Parish 14 SC points out a microscopic organism living in a droplet of water.
Stuffed puffer fish hang from the rafters in the Edna Lawrence Nature Lab.
Students use these skeletal models to draw human figures.
Ctenophora (also known as comb jellies) are predatory marine animals that are propelled by their cilia.
The Cabinet of Curiosities contains a human fetus acquired by RISD in 1996.

caption:
Marvelous cut-out books, mixed media projects and striking posters made by seniors in Graphic Design are on view in Woods-Gerry through April 2.

One of the show’s many wonderful works includes a book by Michelle Mao 13 GD. The handcrafted publication binds together transparent pages that explain the evolution of the household iron. Elsewhere in the gallery, Mari Iwahara 13 GD presents a colorful assortment of parrot-themed postcards she designed while interning at Adobe in New York City last summer. 

The work isn’t all in 2D. Elsewhere in the gallery, Mirali Chatani 13 GD presents a body of sterling silver jewelry cast in geometric shapes that were inspired by graphic design. And Adam Lowe 13 GD shot Identity, a documentary that chronicles the life of a student in RISD’s graphic design department.

Danielle Dodge 08 ID and Seth Snyder 08 ID attended the exhibition’s opening reception last week. Both industrial designers were highly impressed with the diverse array of work. “I didn’t expect to see jewelry at this opening,” notes Dodge. “The exhibition is well worth a visit.”

Click on the images above to see who made these terrific pieces!

Jamie Chong 13 GD created a book inspired by the Post-it notes she accumulated over the course of a week.

caption:
Seniors in Industrial Design recently launched a tongue-in-cheek publicity campaign to lure people to their latest show at Woods-Gerry.

Capitalizing on the cult popularity of home shopping networks, students designed satirical posters advertising fake products including an “Easy-Print Oven” and a “Hammer Weight.” 

“We wanted to include an element of humor into the marketing of the show,” explains Wesley Chau 13 ID. “We were inspired by cheesy late-night infomercials. They’re constanty pumped through the mainstream media and advertise pointless product design. We wanted to have fun with that concept.”

Justin Henry 13 ID (who posed with a “Rag Wow”) made an especially good model. “We really lucked out with Justin,” notes Chau. “He looks just like the guy in the Sham Wow commercials.”

Scroll through the posters to read up on who modeled in these funny faux-advertisements.

caption: President Roger Mandle dropped by today, and we shared a special lunch prepared by RISD Executive Chef Pierre St. Germaine. President Mandle led RISD for the fifteen years prior to my arrival – and we have a building named after him here: The Roger Mandle Building: The Rhode Island School of Design Living and Learning Center – and also our popular eatery, The Jolly Roger. Welcome back to your RISD home Roger! -JM

caption:
Professor Gabriel Feld in our Architecture Department shared with me a few photos of projects by one of our graduates from almost two decades ago, Rahoul Singh. Gabriel writes:

Rahoul shared with me some of his recent work. The office he heads with his wife Lakshmi is moving in scale, from houses and interiors to larger commercial and institutional projects. Here are two images of a recently completed resort that I really loved. Don’t you think that they show an almost bodily sensibility for the materials – the muscle of the stone, the skin of the plaster, the skeleton of the frame, even the eyelashes of the bamboo – and the way they articulate the ground and the sky, the light, and the views of the landscape?

I love the language of the *sensuality* inherent to architecture. If you haven’t checked it out yet, be sure to visit Gabriel’s blog where you can learn all about how to “read” a city: http://citiesandstories.blogspot.com/ -JM

caption:
Last night I was invited by the Graduate and Undergraduate Student Alliances to address a variety of ongoing questions our students had about RISD’s role in our city, in our country, and in our world. After four years here at RISD, I’ve changed how I approach presenting information on campus — and I’ve given up on visual slides as a means of conveying information.

So last night I tried out a new approach. Instead of giving a “power point” presentation, I gave a “power people” presentation. I invited a variety of people who work here at RISD so I could introduce them to our students — thanks to Ed Newhall (any Q on art education in K-12 and STEAM), Jack Silva (any Q on facilities), Annie Newman (any Q on master planning), Patti Phillips (for any Q for research and civic engagement), Jean Eddy (any Q for students), and Babette Allina (any Q on STEAM and the national movement) for so graciously being my “slides” for the *packed* student meeting! http://risd.cc/15rywWE People, especially Ed, Patti, Babette, Jack, Annie, and Jean are SO much better than slides. -JM

PS For students who wish to connect with me, please sign up for office hours when they become available: http://risd.cc/YjLAWX

caption:
On Valentine’s Day, Kevin Cochran 14 PR was enjoying a fantasy many red-blooded men would be happy to entertain. The Printmaking major had his pick of – not one – but six beautiful women. The only downside: they don’t have much depth. 

Cochran’s female companions are part of All My Girlfriends, an exhibition now on display at RISD’s Benson Hall Gallery. Each image is given a girlish moniker and distinct personality. For instance, Cassie is a busty brunette with a seductive gaze. “Everyone thinks she’s the cutest girl in town!” reads the caption.

“These are girls I’d actually be attracted to in real life,” explains Cochran. “I’m actually pretty attached to them at this point. This is my version of utopia.”

To make his lovely ladies, Cochran created the images in DAZ Studio (a sophisticated animation program) and then screenprinted the images onto large swaths of paper.

Aside from being easy on the eyes, Cochran says the pieces make a statement on the way the Internet has skewed modern social conventions. Specifically, the collection was inspired by his fascination with online communities that act out fetishes using Internet avatars.

“For a lot of people, these rendered women can successfully incite human emotions,“ the artist explains. “And that can look a lot like love.”

caption:
New studio work by almost 200 of the extraordinary artists and designers who teach at RISD will be featured at the RISD Museum from February 22 through March 17. The 2013 RISD Faculty Biennial opens with a reception in the Chace Center lobby from 6–8 pm on Thursday, February 21.

A longstanding RISD tradition, the show offers an opportunity for the RISD community and the larger public to appreciate the wide range of ideas, approaches and wonderful examples of making emanating from both full- and part-time faculty members working in almost every medium imaginable (the images above are just the tip of the iceberg, but if you click on them you can see who did what).

As in the past, many faculty artists and designers have created work specifically for the biennial, and there are also a number of collaborative projects being shown this year.

Don’t miss it while it’s up!

caption:
Gracie Canaan 13 ID can be considered a hands-on hostess. Shortly before the clock struck 7 pm on Wednesday night, the industrial designer was hammering nails into a dinner table that would seat a party of 10. Less than an hour later, a merry group was seated at her custom creation munching on organic foods and sipping tasty brew. 

The fun affair was the fruit of Dinner for 10, an independent study project Canaan started last fall as a means of exploring “how the art of cooking and entertaining can be integrated into product, furniture, lighting and interior design,” she says.

But the dinner date didn’t come together as quickly as the table. It took Canaan six months to plan the affair after recruiting students to lend helping hands.

For example, Otis Gray 14 SC built a gorgeous bar that was stocked with drinks provided by Bin 312, a wine cellar that recently opened in downtown Providence. Gayle Forman 14 GL hung delicate lights that cast a warm glow over the space. Daisy Hook 14 IA was responsible for tableware coordination.

And Sarah Lammer 13 PR and Emily Jenne 13 PR helped Canaan secure the location for the party on the second floor of 204 Westminster Street (the same building that houses student orgs RISD Exposé and Second Life). Karen Lee 13 TX and Joseph Escobar 13 ID of Monthly Meal helped provide the locally grown organic food. 

“There’s so much potential for collaboration at this school. I wanted to showcase that potential by throwing a social event where people can connect,” Canaan says. “And it’s nice just to sit down with a homemade meal.”

caption: Last night Arley-Rose Torsone and Morgan Calderini 08 PR, owners of Ladyfingers Letterpress, opened their studio to RISD/RI alumni for a sweet meet-up, complete with treats to eat, bubbly to drink (courtesy of Campus Fine Wines) and a hands-on letterpress-printed valentines project. Located in the Hope Artiste Village, Ladyfingers Letterpress offers luxuriously designed custom invitations and stationery – so keep them in mind for your next event!

caption:
In Designing Space Gloves for NASA – a studio offered by RISD's Apparel and Industrial Design departments – students are thrilled to be designing prototypes for the agency that sent the first astronaut to the moon.

Though NASA has improved the dexterity of the space glove, it’s been at least 40 years since any significant changes were made to the underlying design. And change is greatly needed, say instructors. Poor glove design causes cringe-worthy ailments. For example, when astronauts return home, their fingernails are gone due to a lack of circulation.

Astronauts are “constantly fighting the gloves,” says Senior Critic Michael Lye 96 ID, an instructor of the course. “When the muscles are strained, that’s when injuries occur. That’s not a good thing to happen in space.”

See this story on risd.edu to learn more about the students’ inventive approaches to design!

photos.caption: To test out their creations, students are using a machine-powered vacuum chamber that was constructed by industrial design students.
Maeve Jopsen 13 ID looked to one of nature's most resilient ocean creatures: the lobster. She fashioned a claw-like glove that gives the hand more power by clumping the fingers together.
Zebinah Masse 14 AP constructed an elegant glove that will be incorporated in a final prototype.
Three basic layers make up a NASA space glove. Photo credit: Steve Santaniello
Eugene Liu 16 AP signed up for the class to master the art of glove construction.
Ryan Mather 15 ID shows off his prototype that's made out of ripstop nylon.
Arnold Wong 15 AP (left) says he learns problem solving techniques from industrial designers taking the studio.
Chris Hurbs 15 ID linked up with an Apparel Design major to come up with inventive space glove models.

caption: Professor Randy Willier’s famed “Shirt Show” in our Illustration Studies Building — set for an ambitious upcoming renovation—was jam packed (as usual) with T-shirt motifs ranging from panda bears with antlers, in-your-face sayings, and sheer beauty of patterns. Congratulations Randy and students! -JM

caption: Professor Avishek Ganguly in our Literary Arts and Studies Department appears in a new book entitled The Third World in the Global 1960s, by Samantha Christiansen and Zachary Scarlett. It’s a short piece that highlights the influence of the radical politics of the 1960s on periodical publishing in India, and connects those movements to unfolding events in Europe and the US. Congratulations Avishek! -JM

caption:
This week our 3rd Morisawa Research Fellow, Ryo Kikuchi, presented his current research work in conjunction with his host, Professor Lane Myer, and also Associate Provost Patricia Phillips and Provost Rosanne Somerson. The prior year fellows were Keitaro Sakamoto and Nobu Irie, who are now both back in Japan at Morisawa. Morisawa is Japan’s premier type company – and were the early supporters of the work I did for them in the 90s, that by some freak accident are now in the permanent collection of MoMA.

Ryo’s evolution as a designer from a sales and marketing role (i.e. “non-designer”) has been nothing less than phenomenal. He credits the unique creative community here at RISD that fosters the capacity to fail and experiment – to grow from each risk taken, and to sharpen one’s own creative capacity. Ryo made me wish that I could take RISD classes too! -JM

caption:
On Friday night, students and art lovers checked out Senior Open Studios – a time for RISD undergrads to give tours of lived-in workspaces and chat about amazing projects. Delicate ceramics, beautiful woven textiles and detailed illustrations were all made available for the eye to see.

“It’s just really surprising to see what your peers are actually doing in studio,” noted Michael Ee 15 GD. “They’re doing phenomenal work.”

caption:
Onlookers who attended the Glass Triennial opening last night were eager to get a glimpse of the wonderfully crafted pieces now on display in Woods-Gerry.

“There’s a nice balance in the show,” noted Emma Stein MFA 13 GL. “Traditional craftsmanship and conceptually-based work is definitely well represented.”

Many of the attendees hovered near Celestial Openness, a light installation rigged by Jean Prominski MFA 13 GL. The piece projects soft shadows that create a warm, soothing feeling for the viewer. “I wanted to construct a space that makes people feel like they were in a shower.”

Click through the photos to see who created each thought-provoking piece! The show will be on display through February 17.

caption: Our Vice President of Human Resources Candace Baer shared with me our recent press in Higher Education Workplace Magazine, which features Assistant Registrar, Steven J. Bailey, Executive Director of Planning, Assessment & Quality, Linda Murphy Church, and Executive Director, Strategic Planning & Academic Initiatives, Mara Hermano. Check out our award-winning diversity website as part of our efforts on campus to risdiversify ourselves, as seen in our Strategic Plan: Critical Making | Making Critical. Congratulations! -JM

caption: I am an amateur documentarist (if that is a term) as with many people out there who post to blogs and so forth with the intent of recording what they see and hear. I absolutely love movies, and try to keep up on the latest trends (and I’m always a few years behind). RISD’s produced some extraordinary film industry talent like Gus Van Sant, Robert Richardson, and Seth MacFarlane. And RISD is around, about, seen, and hidden in many other cinematic marvels like Hunger Games and Wes Anderson’s recent Moonrise Kingdom. I noted that the new film 56 Up is a compendium of an early “pre reality TV” experiment in the UK, which of course reminded me of analogous groundbreaking work here in the states with An American Family — which our very own Professor John Terry in our Film, Animation, Video department was an instrumental force in its creation. There is so much work at RISD about reality, and enhancing reality for all of us! -JM

caption:
At the end of 2012 a bevy of books from a variety of friends appeared that I will be sending off to the library shortly.

From Maharam (as in our Maharam STEAM Fellowship program) came this beautiful book on objects made out of paper by Irving Harper. 

From the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation comes their new anthology on how to improve health and health care. Apropos to this book is the special symposium on art, design, and healthcare we held in 2011 sponsored by the RWJF featuring Dr. Howard Koh of the US Department of Health and Human Services.

From one of our alumni, Mr. Richard Parker ‘47, a set of short stories about his many adventures with the inimitable Coco Chanel.

From someone I deeply admire, Niels Diffrient — on his many experiments in the field of industrial design. I had the opportunity to sit with Mr. Diffrient on a panel for the National Design Award one year, long ago.

From another National Design Award recipient and friend, Bruce Nussbaum, comes his take on the creative economy in his forthcoming book Creative Intelligence. It’s a substantive book that takes you from eating live monkey brains (yes, ick) to Junichiro Tanizaki’s famous extended essay, “In Praise of Shadows." 

And lastly a book on typography with a foreword by my friend and designer colleague Erik Spiekermann. By the way, you can never have enough books on type — my favorite one being Bringhurst’s Elements of Typography Style.-JM

caption:
Last month sculptor Jim Drain 98 SC (to the far right in the group photo) and the RISD students who helped him create a site-specific piece for the new US Embassy in Rabat, Morocco were among the RISD people who had a blast at the gala the US State Department held to celebrate the 50th anniversary of its Art in Embassies program.

Also shown in the main photo (l–r) are: artist Kiki Smith, Kelsey Versteeg MIA 12, Danielle Herzenberg MIA 12, artist Jeff Koons, Lindsay Carone MFA 13 SC, Bayne Peterson MFA 13 SC and Carmel Clearwater 14 TX.

Among the other RISD representatives participating in the festivities were Board Chair Michael Spalter, Vice Chair Lisa Pevaroff 83 TX, President John Maeda and Associate Provost Patti Phillips.You can read more about RISD’s involvement here.
