caption:
Architecture alumni Christine Zavesky BArch 08, Thomas Sheridan BArch 08 and Jacqueline Lavin BArch 11 are among the winners in a drawing competition held to help celebrate the upcoming 100th anniversary of New York’s Grand Central Terminal.

As part of the 2013 celebration of the awe-inspiring building, which first opened on February 2, 1913, the Architectural League and the New York Transit Museum invited architects and designers to capture or reimagine the memorable landmark through their own interpretive drawings.

The three drawings above were among the top 20 entries jurors chose for a special edition Grand Central Terminal by Moleskine Sketchbook now available at the Transit Museum Store in Grand Central, the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn and online at the Transit Museum Store. 

“The winning work illustrates the variety of ways architects draw and, perhaps more importantly, the many ways they experience and represent place,” says League Program Director Anne Rieselbach. All in all, as New York Transit Museum Director Gabrielle Shubert points out, the book presents “evidence of the power of the past to awaken us to our future.”

caption: I’ve been having open student office hours for the past two years and noted that the 100th student came to visit me (and also the 101st, 102nd, and 103rd). Pictured above is Dillon Froelich ‘13 who is in Industrial Design and has organized a group show at The LAB Miami for the upcoming Art Basel event. Dillon’s an entrepreneur, so I immediately suggested he visit with Greg Victory and his staff because of all of their work in advancing “artrepreneurship.” Pictured below Dillon are Mateo Ward '13 and James McGurl '13, both in Industrial Design, and Kim Dupont-Madnier '14, from Architecture – just three of the many students who have formed the RISD Pigeon Club. I thought it was interesting how at RISD we engage in relaying short messages via the people a-tweet on Twitter, and also by the old-fashioned means of short messages via bona fide birds! -JM

caption:
Follow along all this week as Lois Harada 10 PR introduces a couple of alumni a day from the hundreds who are selling work at the 2012 RISD Alumni Holiday Sale. The event runs from 10 to 5 this Saturday, December 8, at the RI Convention Center in downtown Providence.

Even if you don’t have a crazy long holiday shopping list, it’s great to go and drink in the exciting outcomes of this much creative energy. You can ask questions, get ideas and buy remarkable handmade gifts you’re proud to give.

And if you’re too far away to get there, check out all the participants here. You can contact alumni directly and support their work via their websites.

caption:
Though superstorm Sandy forced RISD to close for two days earlier this week (and some people just got power back last night), a lot of New York alumni and faculty were harder hit. Photographer Mike Neff 04 PH had to pump out his basement studio in Tribeca and was moved to share photos of the damage in Chelsea on his Facebook and Pinterest pages (Hurricane Sandy vs. the Chelsea Art World).

Note the photo of the Andrea Rosen Gallery doorway, where a solo show of work by Andrea Zittel MFA 90 SC had just closed last Saturday.

caption: There’s nothing like a hurricane to get your desk in good order. Someone gave me this paper by Prof. Andrew Yang at SAIC entitled, “Interdisciplinarity and Critical Inquiry: Visualizing at the Art/Bioscience Interface.” It races two case studies where art and science combine in a way that are neither just about the parts nor just the sum of the parts, but form a new whole. It’s nice to know that STEAM is rising all across America. -JM

caption: Professor Brooks Hagan in our Textiles department recently shared with me about his new collections from Mulberry House in India and Dieu Donne in NYC. Rhode Island was once a thriving center of textile activities in the US, and our Textiles department carries the key DNA of that important era of creativity that married industry and technology with the arts. If you had the chance to see the RISD Textiles show earlier this year at the New York Design Center you would know that textiles at RISD are taken to a wondrous level that is difficult to capture in photographs or texts.  -JM

caption: Professor David Frazer in our Painting department let me know that he has a new show up at the CCRI Knight Campus Gallery running until October 25th. It’s open Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 10-4PM and on Thursdays from 10-7PM. We have one of David’s paintings hung here on the 4th floor of the building I am in. People stop in their tracks, staring into the layers upon layers of visual thoughts and patterns and narratives in his manner of image construction and conception. -JM

caption: Professor Daniel Heyman in our Printmaking department has a profoundly disturbing and beautiful show up at Cade Tompkins Gallery right now here in Providence. Daniel’s experiences as an “artist witness” to the events that unfolded in Iraq are on view, and in addition the set of work hanging on the walls lets you see his genesis as an artist, an international citizen, and as a human being, just like us all. -JM

caption: RISD By Design Alumni and Parents Weekend is underway here at RISD. Check out this great new T-shirt by RISD graduate Duncan Mackenzie — because at RISD it’s all about aesthetics. And the aesthetics present on campus represent families and individuals from all across the US and the entire world. Also helping us formally kickoff RBD were Trustee and former Alumni Association President and sculptor Nat Hesse (podcast is here) who came all the way from New Mexico, and our new Board Chair Michael Spalter who opens the Saturday panel on STEAM. -JM

caption:
Professor Henry Horenstein in our Photography department literally wrote the manual on black and white photography, and recently shared with me his newer manual on digital photography above. Henry’s new text is now in use at many colleges and universities including Tyler School of Art, NYU, MassArt, and many others. I’m excited to get his opinion on the new Lytro light field camera, which I’ll post later. -JM

PS Check out Professor Horenstein’s website to be mesmerized by all that can be done in all shades of black, white, and gray.

caption:
Professor Wendy Seller in Foundation Studies shared with me her new solo exhibition that just opened yesterday in Massachusetts:

This summer, during the month of August, I was an Artist-in-Residence at the Burren College of Art in the tiny town of Ballyvaughan, Ireland, located in the middle of “The Burren”. Just prior to my residency, I explored and documented the western and southern coastal areas of this extraordinary country for eight days. My focus sharpened to encompass the old and ancient castle ruins, houses and churches that are found at every turn throughout Ireland — in residential backyards, on playgrounds, down narrow rutted single-lane roads, in the most unlikely locations. Most of the structures that interested me could not be found on the maps. I was struck by the contrast between the remains of these stone structures (which I found extraordinarily beautiful) and the lush greenery that grew from within them. The inside/outside of these ruins became intriguing dichotomies. In working with these fresh images during my four-week residency, I started an entirely new series. Several of these works are included in my solo show at the Taft Gallery, St. Mark’s School in Southborough, MA. The exhibition runs from October 1 to November 3; hours are 8-8, Monday-Sunday.

For directions please visit this link. -JM

caption:
The self-described twin dandies known as The Brothers Mueller (Kirk and Nate Mueller MFA 10 DM) say they’re out to subvert the “cold, raw, masculine aesthetic of digital art” and offer a more interesting alternative.

As part of Orientation 2012, the twins are returning to RISD tomorrow (Monday, September 10) to talk to all incoming students. They’ll speak about their work at the New York-based RISD design collaborative Studio Mercury – including their award-winning tablet design for Martha Stewart Living.

The Brothers Mueller speak at 7 pm in the RISD Auditorium and the presentation is free and open to everyone.

caption: If you happen to be walking by AS220 on Empire Street in downtown Providence, be sure to look up at the second story windows at the colorful mural created by Joan Wyand 05 CR. Hurray for Foo-thousand Twelve is a public art project Joan created as recipient of AS220’s free culture award for 2012, in which she chose to celebrate community, “because I wanted to affirm our city. It is not about the achievement of one person, but about an entire community collaborative pursuing their dreams.” In addition to the mural, Joan participated in a collaborative performance with international award recipient Guillermo Gómez-Peña.

caption: Portland alums got quite a (re)treat at a reception last Friday at the stunning home of Martha and Anthony Belluschi BArch 66. The iconic Willamette Heights house was designed in 1948 by Tony’s father Pietro, one of the pioneering architects of 20th-century modernism, and recently renovated by Tony.

caption:
Katie Gallagher 09 AP is going to be a very busy girl on September 6: First, she’s launching her new Spring/Summer 2013 Everything Forever collection at The Standard in NYC at 4 pm. The new collection – sponsored by Moroccan Oil, The Standard, MAC and MilkMade – is inspired by the concept of rebirth and purity, drawing from the perceptions of childhood: haunted woods and the fading promises we make as children to be friends forever, an ode to the remnants of our past, ingrained in us and ever-present.

“Despite inflictions, the soul can remain pure,” Katie says in speaking about what influenced her collection this season. “However, everything we do is in us forever.“

After the launch, Katie will join fellow RISD alumni in judging an on-site sketch contest at UO’s Night Out - a collaboration between Urban Outfitters, RISD’s Apparel Department and Philadelphia University. Lots going on!

See more of Katie’s work on her website, her Facebook page, on Pinterest and Instagram. And keep an eye on her new site Katie by Katie Gallagher, where she will launch an e-store later this fall.

caption: Professor Cyrus Highsmith in RISD’s Graphic Design Department has published a new book entitled “Inside Paragraphs: typographic fundamentals” – which grew out of the lectures he prepared for his beginning-level Typography students at RISD. I’ve used several of Cyrus’ typefaces, so it’s great to read how he thinks. Congratulations Cyrus! -JM

caption:
One of our new Trustees, Bob Glass, sent me this pic from the recent Creative Mornings partnered event in San Francisco. Bob let me know that the event in SF sold out in five minutes; I heard from the founder of Creative Mornings, Tina Roth Eisenberg, that many of the events were similarly sold out instantaneously.

For more information on this series of events that spanned 30 cities in the world, here are posts on The Atlantic and Wired about how together with Creative Mornings we advanced the need in our world to turn STEM to STEAM. -JM

caption:
Good news for RISD: our alumni magazine, RISD XYZ, has won a Gold award for Best Overall Magazine (in the circulation under 30,000 category) in the national 2012 CASE Circle of Excellence Awards (see College and University General Interest Magazines).

If you’ve never heard of it, the Council for Advancement and Support of Education is an international professional organization for people who work in the communications, alumni relations, fundraising and advancement areas of colleges and universities around the world.

The 2012 awards are based on work produced and disseminated in 2011, meaning we submitted the Winter, Spring/Summer and Fall 2011 issues of XYZ for consideration. Our Fall 2011 Beauty of Books cover, illustrated by the amazing Chandler O'Leary 03 IL, also earned a separate Bronze award for Excellence in Design. 

Earlier this year RISD XYZ won two Golds in the CASE District 1 competition, which covers the northeast region of the US: one for Best Overall Magazine (circulation under 30,000) and one for Best Design.

XYZmail, the monthly electronic newsletter affiliated with the magazine, won a Bronze in its category in the District 1 awards, where RISD’s primary website also earned an Honorable Mention. Yaaaay!

caption:
The photo from above is taken from the podium on the eve of RISD’s 129th Commencement exercises. The full story is posted here. I addressed the Class of 2012 with the following speech:

A warm welcome to everyone who has gathered here today to celebrate the Class of 2012 at the Rhode Island School of Design’s 129th Commencement ceremony. We have all looked forward to this day for a long time, and all of you here can be proud of this Class’ achievements. Welcome to members of RISD’s Board of Trustees, staff, alumni, curators, librarians, and our inspiring honorary degree recipients. Welcome to Congressman David Cicilline, President Xu Jiang of the China Academy of Art; Lorne Adrain, Chair of the Rhode Island Board of Governors of Higher Education; Stephen Lassonde, Deputy Dean of the College at Brown University; and Laurie White, President of the Providence Chamber of Commerce. And a special welcome and thanks go out to our faculty and parents, and all of those who have come along on your students’ transformative journeys as artists and designers. It’s an emotional day for all of us.

Class of 2012, you and I began at RISD at the same time. It’s been a chaotic economic era for our world, and these bumps even managed to infiltrate many college campuses. But thanks to your passion and spirit, life on the RISD campus has truly flourished. You’ve doubled the number of student-led clubs and organizations in these four years, and this year we even managed to beat our Ivy League neighbor in flag football. We’ve also seen the rebirth of Carr Haus as a student-centered place to be on campus, which just a few weeks ago you dedicated to beloved English Professor Michael Fink. 

Like you, Class of 2012, I’ve been a student for these past four years, and like you, I bet I would barely recognize the person who set foot on campus in the Fall of 2008. I consider myself a lifelong learner, and have spent much of my life as a student myself, or learning from students as a teacher. When I have walked about campus and had a chance to chat with many of you here, I’ve always been inspired by your ability to relentlessly and boldly experiment — or, as Rocco Landesman of the National Endowment for the Arts says, to “productively fail.” 

Rocco put it so well, but you know who put it even better? Thomas Wayne. You may remember him from the powerful moment he shared with his young son, Bruce Wayne, in the motion picture, “Batman Begins.” While playing on his family’s estate, young Bruce accidentally falls into a deep, narrow well, with no ability to escape. He is later rescued by his father, Thomas. Unsettled and disoriented, the rescued Bruce asks his father, “Why do we fall, father?” Thomas looks in his son’s eyes with compassion and love and says, “So we can learn to pick ourselves up.” And later, his last parting words to his child, who would some day become Batman, are, “Don’t be afraid, Bruce.” 

If you have learned one thing here at RISD, it’s not to be afraid. Along with your teachers and parents, I have watched you take risks in your work and find your voice here at RISD as thinkers and makers. I have seen the important fruits of this labor, whether it be a musical to support disaster relief, or a necklace that weighs less than a feather, or a poster that transforms public health policy, or a garment that drapes like a second skin, or a movie about a counterculture hero, or a garden that welcomes community members in growth and liberty.

At the same time, I have found my voice as a leader, and like any artist and designer, I have tried to make sure I led RISD to take some risks. Things like changing to Gmail and Google Apps early on, or introducing the Square payment device to graduating seniors, or making sure we were active on Etsy and Kickstarter, or teaching Processing in the Foundation Studies classes – these are innovations that at the beginning seemed risky, or unnecessary, but are beginning to seem more commonplace. Thanks to our collective efforts, RISD remains a symbolic beacon for fearless, creative thinkers who dare to “productively fail.” 

Throughout these four years, we have both found teachers who have truly inspired us and changed our world-views. One of my favorite moments of this ceremony every year is when RISD faculty are honored with RISD’s highest teaching award, the Frazier Award. In many ways, this is RISD’s greatest honor – for teaching is our highest value, and what’s more, the recipients are selected by our students, faculty, and staff. 

In today’s world, as we strive to adapt to the curving, “jagged” paths of our professional pursuits, we encounter teachers at all ages and in all forms. They can come to us through an intense studio course, a mentor on the job, or a three-minute video online. This year I happened upon a teacher, Professor Marshall Ganz, at a course for nonprofit leaders at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government. Ganz is an expert in grassroots organizing who lectures about what inspires people to act and to make change in the world. 

He says that moving people to action is about telling stories, and that our stories are formed by three ways of knowing. The three ways of knowing are: knowing with the head, knowing with the hands, and knowing with the heart. The head, he says, is how most of the world operates. It’s a cognitive, logical perspective that drives us to identify what things are, literally. I think most of us here at RISD have had the feeling that sometimes the world goes too far in the direction of the head, and it’s how we sometimes get into trouble. 

The heart is what attaches values to things, what gives them meaning, what gives us a feeling. It’s the part that artists and designers have an acute awareness of, better than anyone in the world. And according to Ganz, it’s the part that really drives us to action. We are only truly moved to act when we make an emotional commitment to something that we care about. 

Which brings us to the hands. The hands are our most advanced tools for making, and our RISD education shows us that they are also tools for thinking. Ganz says, “For the hands to be engaged fruitfully, they need both the head and the heart.” In other words, the best making is fueled by questions from the head and passion from the heart.

Above all, the hands are how we act, enact, bring to action, activate. Everyone bear with me and hold your hands up in front of you. You can tell RISD students’ hands have seen a lot of action. And we like the fact that many of you have kept all of your fingers. They are the hands of work. Thoughtful work. Critical work. Critical making. They are torn up, beat up, and have the battle scars – and charcoal stains – to prove it. Your hands have spent these four years devotedly making – critically making   – and these dirty hands form the basis of your practiced power as you enter the world beyond RISD. 

Ganz also says, “Young people come of age with a critical eye and – almost of necessity – hopeful hearts. That’s why young people are often associated with movements for change.” This year saw the first-ever student leaders’ dinner, celebrating the many different homegrown efforts happening on campus. From an alternative spring break project that helped clean up an abandoned local synagogue, to a roving food truck art gallery called Radish, to the Make Big Dreams Expo where students formed a community of support for entrepreneurial pursuits — or as we say at RISD, “art-repreneurship” — your ability to act with both intention and emotion is exceptional. 

Nowhere that I’ve seen in the world embodies the combination of the head, hands, and heart better than RISD. And no students are better prepared to make change in the world than RISD students. 

It is a special pleasure each year to welcome our honorary degree recipients to campus and show them a bit of what RISD is about. This year, I am especially honored to welcome Rebecca Solnit, Wang Shu, and Studio Ghibli. Yes, we all love Totoro. 

I was speaking in China and Korea last week where I felt the immense creative energy and economic momentum that fills the Asian air now. Our global creative climate is vast, and the fact that two of our honorees would come from Asia is unprecedented and especially relevant to our times. Growing up here in the U.S. as an Asian-American, teachers told me I was good at art, and good at math. And my father would always tell people “My son is good at math.” Even after going on to earn a PhD in design in Japan, I personally encountered much of the skepticism and stereotypes that beset Asian creativity – the belief of that we tend towards “copy cat” culture and a lack of originality. Our honorees from Asia today, Xu Jiang, Wang Shu and Studio Ghibli, show how misguided these assumptions are, and set a high standard for all to emulate. We must embrace influences from the world over. We also must welcome students from backgrounds of all kinds, which is why I am so committed to raising funds for scholarships, and am pleased that we had a record-setting year in this regard. 

Class of 2012, you are local and global citizens — “glocal” citizens — who act in ways that move the hands, minds, and hearts of the world. I knew this from the very moment when I met the incoming class of 2012. 

RISD is the art and design school by which all others are measured, and it is you, the Class of 2012, that make it worthy of its reputation. The entire world is waking up to the fact that art and design will drive economic development in the 21st century like science and technology did in the 20th century. Yes, art and design will be the forces that will carry society forward — or as we have been saying here at RISD, they will turn STEM into STEAM. The best argument for what an arts and design degree can do is what you will do with it. We began here at RISD together, and together, we are showing the world the immense power of art and design, and what can happen when you unite head, hands, and heart.

Thank you for all of the hard, heartful work that brought you to this day, and congratulations to you and your families.

Thanks to everyone who came from near and far! And congratulations once again to the RISD’s Class of 2012! -JM

*Also see the post on Professors White and West, who were honored at Commencement with the 2012 Frazier Award for Excellence in Teaching.

**See the storify-ed link here.

The photo from above is taken from the podium on the eve of RISD’s 129th Commencement exercises. The full story is posted here. I addressed the Class of 2012 with the following speech:

A warm welcome to everyone who has gathered here today to celebrate the Class of 2012 at the Rhode Island School of Design’s 129th Commencement ceremony. We have all looked forward to this day for a long time, and all of you here can be proud of this Class’ achievements. Welcome to members of RISD’s Board of Trustees, staff, alumni, curators, librarians, and our inspiring honorary degree recipients. Welcome to Congressman David Cicilline, President Xu Jiang of the China Academy of Art; Lorne Adrain, Chair of the Rhode Island Board of Governors of Higher Education; Stephen Lassonde, Deputy Dean of the College at Brown University; and Laurie White, President of the Providence Chamber of Commerce. And a special welcome and thanks go out to our faculty and parents, and all of those who have come along on your students’ transformative journeys as artists and designers. It’s an emotional day for all of us.

Class of 2012, you and I began at RISD at the same time. It’s been a chaotic economic era for our world, and these bumps even managed to infiltrate many college campuses. But thanks to your passion and spirit, life on the RISD campus has truly flourished. You’ve doubled the number of student-led clubs and organizations in these four years, and this year we even managed to beat our Ivy League neighbor in flag football. We’ve also seen the rebirth of Carr Haus as a student-centered place to be on campus, which just a few weeks ago you dedicated to beloved English Professor Michael Fink. 

Like you, Class of 2012, I’ve been a student for these past four years, and like you, I bet I would barely recognize the person who set foot on campus in the Fall of 2008. I consider myself a lifelong learner, and have spent much of my life as a student myself, or learning from students as a teacher. When I have walked about campus and had a chance to chat with many of you here, I’ve always been inspired by your ability to relentlessly and boldly experiment — or, as Rocco Landesman of the National Endowment for the Arts says, to “productively fail.” 

Rocco put it so well, but you know who put it even better? Thomas Wayne. You may remember him from the powerful moment he shared with his young son, Bruce Wayne, in the motion picture, “Batman Begins.” While playing on his family’s estate, young Bruce accidentally falls into a deep, narrow well, with no ability to escape. He is later rescued by his father, Thomas. Unsettled and disoriented, the rescued Bruce asks his father, “Why do we fall, father?” Thomas looks in his son’s eyes with compassion and love and says, “So we can learn to pick ourselves up.” And later, his last parting words to his child, who would some day become Batman, are, “Don’t be afraid, Bruce.” 

If you have learned one thing here at RISD, it’s not to be afraid. Along with your teachers and parents, I have watched you take risks in your work and find your voice here at RISD as thinkers and makers. I have seen the important fruits of this labor, whether it be a musical to support disaster relief, or a necklace that weighs less than a feather, or a poster that transforms public health policy, or a garment that drapes like a second skin, or a movie about a counterculture hero, or a garden that welcomes community members in growth and liberty.

At the same time, I have found my voice as a leader, and like any artist and designer, I have tried to make sure I led RISD to take some risks. Things like changing to Gmail and Google Apps early on, or introducing the Square payment device to graduating seniors, or making sure we were active on Etsy and Kickstarter, or teaching Processing in the Foundation Studies classes – these are innovations that at the beginning seemed risky, or unnecessary, but are beginning to seem more commonplace. Thanks to our collective efforts, RISD remains a symbolic beacon for fearless, creative thinkers who dare to “productively fail.” 

Throughout these four years, we have both found teachers who have truly inspired us and changed our world-views. One of my favorite moments of this ceremony every year is when RISD faculty are honored with RISD’s highest teaching award, the Frazier Award. In many ways, this is RISD’s greatest honor – for teaching is our highest value, and what’s more, the recipients are selected by our students, faculty, and staff. 

In today’s world, as we strive to adapt to the curving, “jagged” paths of our professional pursuits, we encounter teachers at all ages and in all forms. They can come to us through an intense studio course, a mentor on the job, or a three-minute video online. This year I happened upon a teacher, Professor Marshall Ganz, at a course for nonprofit leaders at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government. Ganz is an expert in grassroots organizing who lectures about what inspires people to act and to make change in the world. 

He says that moving people to action is about telling stories, and that our stories are formed by three ways of knowing. The three ways of knowing are: knowing with the head, knowing with the hands, and knowing with the heart. The head, he says, is how most of the world operates. It’s a cognitive, logical perspective that drives us to identify what things are, literally. I think most of us here at RISD have had the feeling that sometimes the world goes too far in the direction of the head, and it’s how we sometimes get into trouble. 

The heart is what attaches values to things, what gives them meaning, what gives us a feeling. It’s the part that artists and designers have an acute awareness of, better than anyone in the world. And according to Ganz, it’s the part that really drives us to action. We are only truly moved to act when we make an emotional commitment to something that we care about. 

Which brings us to the hands. The hands are our most advanced tools for making, and our RISD education shows us that they are also tools for thinking. Ganz says, “For the hands to be engaged fruitfully, they need both the head and the heart.” In other words, the best making is fueled by questions from the head and passion from the heart.

Above all, the hands are how we act, enact, bring to action, activate. Everyone bear with me and hold your hands up in front of you. You can tell RISD students’ hands have seen a lot of action. And we like the fact that many of you have kept all of your fingers. They are the hands of work. Thoughtful work. Critical work. Critical making. They are torn up, beat up, and have the battle scars – and charcoal stains – to prove it. Your hands have spent these four years devotedly making – critically making   – and these dirty hands form the basis of your practiced power as you enter the world beyond RISD. 

Ganz also says, “Young people come of age with a critical eye and – almost of necessity – hopeful hearts. That’s why young people are often associated with movements for change.” This year saw the first-ever student leaders’ dinner, celebrating the many different homegrown efforts happening on campus. From an alternative spring break project that helped clean up an abandoned local synagogue, to a roving food truck art gallery called Radish, to the Make Big Dreams Expo where students formed a community of support for entrepreneurial pursuits — or as we say at RISD, “art-repreneurship” — your ability to act with both intention and emotion is exceptional. 

Nowhere that I’ve seen in the world embodies the combination of the head, hands, and heart better than RISD. And no students are better prepared to make change in the world than RISD students. 

It is a special pleasure each year to welcome our honorary degree recipients to campus and show them a bit of what RISD is about. This year, I am especially honored to welcome Rebecca Solnit, Wang Shu, and Studio Ghibli. Yes, we all love Totoro. 

I was speaking in China and Korea last week where I felt the immense creative energy and economic momentum that fills the Asian air now. Our global creative climate is vast, and the fact that two of our honorees would come from Asia is unprecedented and especially relevant to our times. Growing up here in the U.S. as an Asian-American, teachers told me I was good at art, and good at math. And my father would always tell people “My son is good at math.” Even after going on to earn a PhD in design in Japan, I personally encountered much of the skepticism and stereotypes that beset Asian creativity – the belief of that we tend towards “copy cat” culture and a lack of originality. Our honorees from Asia today, Xu Jiang, Wang Shu and Studio Ghibli, show how misguided these assumptions are, and set a high standard for all to emulate. We must embrace influences from the world over. We also must welcome students from backgrounds of all kinds, which is why I am so committed to raising funds for scholarships, and am pleased that we had a record-setting year in this regard. 

Class of 2012, you are local and global citizens — “glocal” citizens — who act in ways that move the hands, minds, and hearts of the world. I knew this from the very moment when I met the incoming class of 2012. 

RISD is the art and design school by which all others are measured, and it is you, the Class of 2012, that make it worthy of its reputation. The entire world is waking up to the fact that art and design will drive economic development in the 21st century like science and technology did in the 20th century. Yes, art and design will be the forces that will carry society forward — or as we have been saying here at RISD, they will turn STEM into STEAM. The best argument for what an arts and design degree can do is what you will do with it. We began here at RISD together, and together, we are showing the world the immense power of art and design, and what can happen when you unite head, hands, and heart.

Thank you for all of the hard, heartful work that brought you to this day, and congratulations to you and your families.

Thanks to everyone who came from near and far! And congratulations once again to the RISD’s Class of 2012! -JM

*Also see the post on Professors White and West, who were honored at Commencement with the 2012 Frazier Award for Excellence in Teaching.

We must embrace influences from the world over. We also must welcome students from backgrounds of all kinds, which is why I am so committed to raising funds for scholarships, and am pleased that we had a record-setting year in this regard. 

Class of 2012, you are local and global citizens — “glocal” citizens — who act in ways that move the hands, minds, and hearts of the world. I knew this from the very moment when I met the incoming class of 2012. 

RISD is the art and design school by which all others are measured, and it is you, the Class of 2012, that make it worthy of its reputation. The entire world is waking up to the fact that art and design will drive economic development in the 21st century like science and technology did in the 20th century. Yes, art and design will be the forces that will carry society forward — or as we have been saying here at RISD, they will turn STEM into STEAM. The best argument for what an arts and design degree can do is what you will do with it. We began here at RISD together, and together, we are showing the world the immense power of art and design, and what can happen when you unite head, hands, and heart.

Thank you for all of the hard, heartful work that brought you to this day, and congratulations to you and your families.

Thanks to everyone who came from near and far! And congratulations once again to the RISD's Class of 2012! -JM

*Also see the post on Professors White and West, who were honored at Commencement with the 2012 Frazier Award for Excellence in Teaching.

**See the storify-ed link here.

caption: RISD Apparel Department graduate Tae Ashida let me know about her recent show in Tokyo at Mitsui Hall in Japan. In case you can’t read Japanese, it says “Subtle use of blacks, red, gold, and bright colors layer into the sculptural, artistic forms of Ashida.” Congratulations, Tae! -JM

caption:
The RISD folk band Celadour played thoughtfully magical sounds at our recent scholarship luncheon (an event that we have proudly doubled in size – testament to the fact that we have raised more funds for scholarships over the last few years than RISD’s entire 130+ year history). You can enjoy Celadour’s tunes on campus or online via the RISD Music Project. -JM 

PS Celadour has a Kickstarter project to raise funds to pay for gas on their June tour, with just a few days left.

caption:
Congratulations to Sanya Kantarovsky 04 PT, named by Home+Design magazine as one of California’s Top 10 Artists You Need To Know in 2012.

The judges, including LA County Museum of Art Chief Curator of Contemporary Art Franklin Sirmans, praised the Russian native and LA resident’s work as art that “deftly evokes … complex internal landscapes through familiar motifs: cartoony, faceless figures and simple geometric forms make frequent appearances on his melancholy canvases.”

Sanya’s latest solo show, Blue Notebook No. 10, is on view through this Saturday at the Marc Foxx Gallery in LA.
